questions.text: A 30-year-old man came with choking episodes after ingestion of fish bone while eating. The fishbone got impacted at the level of T4 in the esophagus. Which is the most likely site of obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Arch of aorta

Explanation:

  • The fishbone is impacted at the T4 level, where the aortic arch crosses the esophagus and creates a normal anatomical narrowing, making it the most likely site of obstruction.

Oesophageal Constrictions:

  • Constrictions occur at four main points:

Point of constriction

Distance from Incisors

Description

Vertebral level

Cricopharyngeus Muscle

(Option C ruled out)

6 inches

This first constriction is at the upper esophageal sphincter where the esophagus begins. It is caused by the cricopharyngeus muscle, which plays a role in swallowing.

C6

Aortic Arch

(Option B)

9 inches

The second narrowing occurs where the arch of the aorta crosses the esophagus. The pressure from the aorta causes this indentation.

T4

Left Main Bronchus

(Option A ruled out)

11 inches

Third constriction is where the left bronchus crosses over the esophagus, leading to a narrowing.

T6

Diaphragmatic Hiatus

(Option D ruled out)

15 inches

The final narrowing happens where the esophagus passes through the diaphragm at the esophageal hiatus.

T10

questions.text: A man fell on his shoulder with his head pushed in the opposite direction. He presented with the following deformity. Which nerve root values are most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - C5 and C6:

Explanation:

  • A fall on the shoulder with the head pushed to the opposite side suggests a traction injury to the upper brachial plexus, resulting in the characteristic posture seen in Erb’s Palsy, most commonly affecting the C5 and C6 nerve roots.

Erb’s Palsy

Definition

Erb-Duchenne palsy results from damage to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5 and C6 nerve roots). (Option A)

Mechanism of Injury

Traction or stretching of the neck during childbirth (shoulder dystocia) or traumatic separation of the head and shoulder.

Anatomical Structures Involved

Brachial Plexus: Formed by ventral rami of C5-T1 spinal nerves

Upper Trunk: Union of C5 and C6 ventral rami

Erb’s Point: Located in the posterior triangle of the neck, where the upper trunk divides into anterior and posterior divisions.

Clinical Presentation
  • Muscle Weakness/ Paralysis
    • Shoulder Abduction: Affected (supraspinatus, deltoid)
    • External Rotation: Affected (infraspinatus, teres minor)
    • Elbow Flexion: Affected (biceps brachii, brachialis)
    • Forearm Supination: Affected (biceps brachii)
  • Arm Position: Limp arm by the side, forearm pronated, hand inward ("waiter’s tip" position).
  • Sensory Deficits: Numbness or tingling along the lateral arm, forearm, and hand, corresponding to C5 and C6 dermatomes.

Associated findings
  • Horner's Syndrome: Involvement of T1 nerve root, indicating a more extensive injury.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: Bone deformities (e.g., glenoid dysplasia, clavicular shortening) due to muscle imbalance.

Incorrect Options: 

  • C6 and C7 (Option B) involves the middle trunk of the brachial plexus, which is not typically affected by traction injuries from shoulder falls; it doesn't produce the classic Erb’s palsy posture.
  • C7 and C8 (Option C) affects the lower part of the brachial plexus, leading to deficits in wrist and finger movements rather than the shoulder and elbow posture characteristic of Erb’s palsy.
  • C8 and T1 (Option D) involves the lower trunk, typically injured by upward traction of the arm, resulting in Klumpke’s palsy with hand muscle weakness, not the upper limb findings seen here.

questions.text: Which structure is formed by the structure indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Nucleus pulposus:

Explanation:

  • The arrow points to the Notochord, an embryonic midline structure that acts as the primitive axial skeleton, induces neural tube formation, and later forms the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc in adults.

  • Nucleus pulposus: The core of the intervertebral disc, derived from the embryonic notochord, and functions to absorb spinal compression and provide flexibility.
  • Notochord Formation:
    • Formation of the primitive streak
    • Migration of mesodermal cells through the primitive node
    • Formation of the notochordal process
    • Formation of the notochordal plate
    • Detachment of the notochordal plate
    • Rolling into the definitive notochord

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Annulus (Option A) refers to the annulus fibrosus, the outer fibrous ring of the intervertebral disc, which does not originate from the notochord, but from mesoderm (sclerotome).
  • Neural tube (Option C) forms from the ectoderm, induced by signals from the notochord, but it is not formed by the notochord itself.
  • Septum transversum (Option D) contributes to the diaphragm and develops from mesoderm, unrelated to the notochord.

questions.text: A diabetic worker sustains a stab injury to the central region of his palm. After 3 days, he develops swelling, severe pain, and inability to extend his middle and ring fingers. Pus accumulation is suspected in one of the palmar spaces. Which of the following spaces is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - B:

Explanation:

  • A stab injury to the central palm in a diabetic patient, followed by swelling, pain, and inability to extend the middle and ring fingers, suggests pus accumulation in the midpalmar space (B) - a deep space bounded by the palmar aponeurosis and metacarpals, commonly involved in deep hand infections affecting the 3rd and 4th digits.

Incorrect Options:

  • Hypothenar space (Option A): Located on the ulnar side of the palm, involving the little finger - not the middle and ring fingers.
  • Thenar space (Option C): Found on the radial side of the palm, associated with the thumb and index finger, not the central palm.
  • Dorsal subaponeurotic space (Option D): Located on the dorsum of the hand, not the palm - not relevant in this scenario.

questions.text: Which is the narrowest part of the adult laryngeal airway?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Glottis:

Explanation:

In adults, the glottis- specifically the rima glottidis, the space between the true vocal cords - is the narrowest part of the laryngeal airway and plays a key role in controlling airflow and voice production.

 

Infant Larynx 

Adult Larynx 

Position

Superiorly placed (C1-C4)

3rd -6th cervical vertebrae (C3-C6)

Epiglottis

Omega-shaped, floppy

Leaf like

Narrowest area

Subglottis

Glottis (Option B)

Submucosal tissue

More abundant

Less abundant

Incorrect Options:

  • Supraglottic region (Option A) includes the structures above the vocal cords (like the epiglottis and false vocal cords), and it is wider than the glottis.
  • Subglottic region (Option C) is located below the vocal cords; it's wider than the glottis in adults but is the narrowest part in children.
  • Trachea (Option D) is significantly wider than the glottis.

questions.text: A doctor receives two summons, one to appear in court in a murder case and another to provide expert medical opinion. Which of the following should the doctor prioritise?

choices.text: Appearance for providing medical expert opinion

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Appearance in the murder case

Explanation:

  • A criminal court summons in a murder case generally carries a legal imperative and higher priority; attendance is mandatory unless legally excused.
  • Providing expert opinion is important, but when faced with a direct court order in a criminal case, the legal obligation to appear in court for the criminal matter is prioritized.

Incorrect Options:

Appearance for expert opinion (Option B): Important but typically subordinate to a direct criminal court summons.

The summon received first (Option C): The timing of receipt does not override the legal gravity of a murder case summons.

questions.text: A man sustained trauma on the lateral side of his right knee. Two days later, he complains of difficulty in walking, as his toes keep dragging on the ground. He also notices numbness over the upper lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Common peroneal nerve:

Explanation:

A man with lateral right knee trauma now has foot drop and numbness over the upper lateral leg and dorsum of the foot, indicating injury to the Common Peroneal Nerve.

  • Supply: Common peroneal nerve branches from the sciatic nerve. It wraps around the neck of the fibula and then divides into two major branches:
    • Superficial peroneal nerve → Peroneus longus and Peroneus brevis (motor supply) → Eversion of the foot.
    • Deep peroneal nerve → Dorsiflexion of the foot and toes and extension of the toes (motor supply)
      • Tibialis anterior
      • Extensor hallucis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
      • Extensor digitorum brevis
  • Mechanism of Trauma: Trauma to the lateral side of the knee, especially around the fibular neck, is a common site of injury to the common peroneal nerve, where it is superficial and vulnerable.
  • Symptoms:
    • Foot drop (toes drag while walking) → due to loss of dorsiflexion (caused by paralysis of muscles innervated by the deep peroneal nerve).
    • Numbness over the upper lateral leg and dorsum of foot → sensory supply of the common peroneal nerve and its superficial branch.

Incorrect Options:

  • Tibial nerve (Option A) affects plantarflexion and sensation on the sole of the foot - not consistent with symptoms.
  • Deep peroneal nerve (Option C) controls dorsiflexion but doesn't explain sensory loss over the lateral leg and most of the dorsum of the foot.
  • Femoral nerve (Option D) innervates anterior thigh muscles - not involved in foot dorsiflexion or lateral leg sensation.

questions.text: A young patient experiences shortness of breath specifically during exercise in winter, which subsides after using salbutamol. What is the most likely explanation for this condition?

choices.text: Vagal stimulation due to cold air exposure
Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction triggered by cold air
Airway hyperreactivity due to cold-induced asthma exacerbation

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction triggered by cold air:

Explanation:

Shortness of breath during winter exercise relieved by salbutamol suggests Exercise-Induced Bronchoconstriction, triggered by cold air in individuals with airway hyperresponsiveness.

Exercise-Induced Bronchoconstriction

Definition

Transient narrowing of airways during or after exercise

Triggers

  • Cold, dry air (common in winter) (Option C)
  • Intense physical activity

Mechanism

Loss of heat and moisture from airways → airway hyperreactivity → bronchoconstriction (Option C)

Symptoms

  • Commonly seen in:
    • Young individuals
    • Underlying asthma or allergies
  • Shortness of breath
  • Wheezing
  • Coughing during/after exercise

Diagnosis

Exercise challenge test or spirometry

Management

  • Salbutamol (β2-agonist) inhaled before exercise
  • Avoid cold air exposure (e.g., use a mask or warm-up before exercise).

Incorrect Options:

Vagal stimulation due to cold air exposure (Option A): More likely to cause nasal symptoms or bradycardia, not exercise-specific dyspnea.

Decreased cardiac output stimulates baroreceptors (Option B): Would not typically cause exercise-induced respiratory symptoms that resolve with bronchodilators.

Airway hyperreactivity due to cold-induced asthma exacerbation (Option D): Close, but this would imply a general asthma attack, not specifically exercise-induced. The key feature in this case is exercise as the trigger.

questions.text: During an explosion, a patient sustains a crushed lower limb injury by collapse of a building. What type of blast injury does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Quaternary

Explanation:

  • Quaternary blast injuries include building collapse causing crush injuries.

Primary blast injury (Option A)

  • Air-wave/ blast wave/ shock wave - Air compression
  • Barotrauma damages hollow organs
    • Ear
      • Tympanic membrane- M/c, Ossicles, Bleeding, perforation
    • Lungs
      • Most fatal injury
      • Alveoli, capillaries injured (blast lung)
    • GIT
      • Vomiting, Perforation, Hematemesis, Melena

Secondary blast injury (Option B)

  • Flying missiles/ projectiles/ objects - Hitting body
    • Bruises
    • Abrasions
    • Punctate laceration

Tertiary blast injury (Option C)

  • Lifted and thrown around
    • Hits ground
    • Skeletal fractures/ displacements

Quaternary blast injury

  • Miscellaneous
    • Building collapse: Traumatic Asphyxia
    • Burn, Flame injuries

Quinary Blast Injuries

  • Environmental contaminants
  • Chemicals (Chloride, Savin)
  • Radiations (nuclear bomb)
  • Virus and bacteria.

questions.text: The upper part of the uncinate process commonly attaches to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Middle turbinate:

Explanation:

  • The uncinate process is a thin, curved bony structure of the ethmoid bone that extends superiorly and typically attaches to the middle nasal concha (middle turbinate), helping to form part of the lateral nasal wall and the drainage pathway of the frontal sinus.

Components of the Middle Meatus of the Nose:

  • Uncinate Process:
    • Hook-like structure running from anterosuperior to posteroinferior.
    • Forms a gap with the bulla ethmoidalis called the hiatus semilunaris inferior.
    • Divides the lower middle meatus into anterior and posterior fontanelles (membranous areas).
  • Infundibulum:
    • Bounded medially by the uncinate process and laterally by the lamina papyracea.
    • Contains the natural ostium of the maxillary sinus in its lower part.
  • Bulla Ethmoidalis:
    • Ethmoidal cell located behind the uncinate process, forming the posterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris.
    • May be pneumatized or a solid prominence.
  • Hiatus Semilunaris:
    • Inferior: The gap between the uncinate process and bulla.
    • Superior: The cleft between the bulla and skull base.
  • Ostiomeatal Unit (Complex):
    • Key area where the ostia of the frontal, ethmoidal, and maxillary sinuses drain into the middle meatus.
    • Common drainage pathway for the anterior group of sinuses.

Incorrect Options:

Superior turbinate (Option B): The uncinate process does not attach here; it is located lower than the superior turbinate.

Inferior turbinate (Option C): This is a separate bone and much lower in the nasal cavity, so the uncinate process doesn’t attach to it.

Bulla ethmoidalis (Option D): This is a separate ethmoid air cell located posterior to the uncinate process, not an attachment site.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with pinpoint pupils and difficulty breathing after playing at home. What is the most likely substance the child accidentally ingested?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Opioid

Explanation:

  • Opioid ingestion classically causes miosis (pin-point pupils) and respiratory depression — the hallmark of opioid toxicity.

Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning

Cause

Clinical, accidental, or suicidal overdose.

Symptoms
  • Unconsiousness/coma
  • Miosis: Pin point pupil
  • Respiratory depression
  • Dry secretion in the eye/mouth
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Flaccid muscles
  • Convulsions (in children)

Management

Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote)

                    ↓

Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):

  • Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol
  • Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine

                       ↓

Abstinence (Prevent relapse):

  • DOC: Oral Naltrexone

questions.text: What best describes step 3 in the given diagram?

choices.text: Resting membrane potential is maintained by the Na-K pump

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Efflux of K ions

Explanation:

Step 3 – Repolarisation occurs as voltage-gated K⁺ channels open, causing K⁺ efflux, which restores the membrane potential toward its resting level.

Process

Membrane Potential Change

Ion Movement/Channel Activity

Threshold Impact

Resting Potential

~ -65 mV

Higher K⁺ inside than outside

Neutral

Depolarization

More positive

Na⁺ influx (channels open)

Possible Action Potential

EPSP

More positive

Positive ions enter

Triggers Action Potential if threshold reached

Repolarization

Returns to -65 mV

from peak of depolarization

Na⁺ channels close, K⁺ channels open wider

Returns to resting state

Hyperpolarization

More negative than -65 mV

Cl⁻ enters or K⁺ exits (channels remain open)

Less likely to fire immediately

IPSP

More negative

Negative ions enter or K⁺ exits

Inhibits action potential

Incorrect Options:

Efflux of Na ions (Option A): Not involved in repolarisation; Na⁺ channels are already inactivated.

Influx of Na ions (Option B): Happens during depolarisation, not repolarisation.

Resting membrane potential is maintained by the Na-K pump (Option D): True in general, but not specific to the repolarisation phase.

questions.text: In the given image which vein is mainly affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Great saphenous vein:

Explanation:

  • The image depicts varicose veins following the path of the great saphenous vein, the primary vein affected is the great saphenous vein.

Great Saphenous Vein (GSV)

Origin
  • Arises on the dorsum of the foot, as a continuation of the medial marginal vein

Course
  • Ascends in front of the medial malleolus
  • Runs along the medial leg
  • Courses behind the knee
  • Inclines forward in the thigh
  • Passes through the saphenous opening into the femoral vein

Tributaries
  • Dorsal venous arch of the foot
  • Medial marginal vein
  • Posterior arch vein
  • Calf vein
  • Accessory saphenous vein
  • Anterior cutaneous vein of the thigh
  • Superficial epigastric, circumflex iliac, and external pudendal veins

Valves
  • Contains 10-20 valves, more concentrated in the leg

Clinical Significance
  • Commonly used in surgical grafting, especially for coronary artery bypass
  • Varicose veins: Dilated, tortuous veins due to valve incompetence, commonly in GSV and tributaries

Incorrect Options:

Short saphenous vein (Option B) runs along the posterior leg and is less commonly affected.

Femoral vein (Option C) is a deep vein, and varicosities usually involve superficial veins.

Perforator veins (Option D) connect superficial veins to deep veins but are not the primary site of varicosities.

questions.text: Which among the following hormones, in a lactating mother, is responsible for the growth of breast tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Prolactin

Explanation:

In a lactating mother, prolactin is primarily responsible for stimulating the growth and development of the milk-producing breast tissue (lobuloalveolar structures).

Prolactin

Source

Secreted by lactotrophs of the anterior pituitary (number increase during pregnancy, lactation, estrogen therapy)

Synthesis
  • Synthesized as preprolactin → proprolactin → prolactin
  • Stored in granules of lactotrophs → secreted upon stimulation

Factors Controlling Secretion

Increased by:

  • Prolactin Releasing Factor (PRF)
  • Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone (TRH) (B)
  • Pregnancy, estrogen therapy, breastfeeding
  • Sleep, stress (D)
  • Oxytocin, serotonin, Angiotensin-II (A)
  • Dopamine antagonists, opioids

Decreased by:

  • Dopamine and its agonists
  • Somatostatin, GABA
  • Prolactin (feedback mechanism)

Functions
  • Milk Synthesis and Secretion: Stimulates milk synthesis and secretion
  • Breast Development:
    • Hyperplasia of breast tissue (puberty, pregnancy and lactation)
    • Stimulates development of mammary glands
    • Works with estrogen, progesterone, cortisol, GH, insulin
  • Reproductive Functions:
    • Inhibits GnRH (prevents ovulation,cause lactational amenorrhea)
    • Inhibition of libido, stimulation of maternal behaviour
    • Decreases spermatogenesis in males
  • Immunity: Synthesized by immunocytes (balance immune response during pregnancy).
  • Liver: Increases synthesis of synlactin (intermediary growth factor).

Clinical Correlation
  • Amenorrhea-galactorrhea syndrome due to hyperprolactinemia
  • Diagnosis: High plasma prolactin levels, pituitary MRI
  • Treatment: Dopaminergic drugs to inhibit prolactin secretion, restoring fertility and libido

Incorrect Options:

Oxytocin (Option A) triggers milk ejection (let-down reflex), not growth.

Estrogen (Option B) stimulates ductal growth in the breast tissue and also promotes overall breast enlargement and structural development.

Progesterone (Option D) supports lobuloalveolar development, preparing the breast for milk production.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient is admitted to the hospital 48 hours after his last drink. He presents with altered consciousness, disorientation, and severe agitation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Delirium tremens

Explanation:

  • Based on the timing (48 hours), severe agitation, and altered mental status in this patient strongly point to Delirium tremens rather than simple alcohol withdrawal or other causes.
  • Delirium tremens is the most severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal, typically occurring 48–72 hours after the last drink. It presents with altered consciousness, disorientation, severe agitation, autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever), and sometimes hallucinations.
  • DT is a medical emergency with high mortality if untreated (5–15%). It is caused by CNS hyperexcitability due to the sudden removal of chronic ethanol’s depressant effect.

Management: ICU care, high-dose benzodiazepines, thiamine supplementation, and supportive measures.

Risk factors:

  • Prior severe withdrawal
  • Concurrent illness
  • Heavy, prolonged alcohol use.

Time since last drink

Common features

Severe complications

6–12 hrs

Tremors, anxiety, insomnia, GI upset

—

12–24 hrs

Visual/tactile hallucinations

—

24–48 hrs

Seizures (generalized tonic-clonic)

—

48–72 hrs

Confusion, agitation, autonomic instability → Delirium tremens

Death if untreated

 

Incorrect Options:

Alcohol withdrawal symptoms (Option B): This is a broad term that includes all manifestations after cessation of alcohol; however, this patient’s severe agitation and altered consciousness indicate Delirium tremens, the most severe form, not just mild/moderate withdrawal.

Cocaine intoxication (Option C): Can cause agitation and confusion, but typically occurs during or shortly after use, not 48 hrs after stopping alcohol. Also accompanied by mydriasis, chest pain, hypertension, and arrhythmias.

Korsakoff psychosis (Option D): A late complication of thiamine deficiency (often following untreated Wernicke encephalopathy) with irreversible anterograde/retrograde amnesia and confabulation; it is chronic, not acute like DT.

questions.text: A deceased woman was sent for an autopsy. She was found dead in a locked room with a heat stove still running. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. CO poisoning

Explanation:

  • A locked room with a running heat stove is a classic setup for carbon monoxide (CO) accumulation due to incomplete combustion of fuel. CO binds to hemoglobin with ~200–250 times the affinity of oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin and impairing oxygen delivery to tissues. This results in hypoxic injury and death.
  • CO poisoning often occurs in enclosed spaces with faulty heaters, stoves, or car exhaust.
  • Clinical features include headache, dizziness, cherry-red skin, confusion, and loss of consciousness. Death results from tissue hypoxia despite normal PaO₂.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by elevated carboxyhemoglobin levels.

Treatment: Immediate removal from the source and administration of 100% oxygen or hyperbaric oxygen therapy in severe cases.

Poison

Post-mortem Staining

Carbon monoxide

Cherry red

Cyanide

Brick red / Bright red

Hypothermia

Pink

Opiates

Black

Hydrogen sulfide

Bluish green

Aniline

Dark / Deep blue or brown

Phosphorus

Dark brown

Nitrates

Reddish brown

Asphyxia

Dark blue

Septic abortion (Clostridium perfringens)

Pale bronze

Incorrect Options:

Cyanide poisoning (Option B): Occurs in industrial accidents or smoke inhalation from fires; causes rapid onset of severe lactic acidosis and cardiovascular collapse, not typically associated with a running stove in a locked room.

H₂S poisoning (Option C): Hydrogen sulfide is found in sewage, petroleum, and industrial environments; it presents with a rotten-egg odor and rapid respiratory failure, not with the enclosed-room heating scenario.

Aluminium phosphide poisoning (Option D): Common in agricultural suicide cases; releases phosphine gas when exposed to moisture, causing severe cardiac toxicity, not linked to household heating sources.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with ophthalmoplegia and ptosis. Diagnosis of superior orbital fissure syndrome was confirmed after examination. Which nerves are compressed in this case ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - III, IV, V1, VI

Explanation:

  • Superior orbital fissure syndrome compresses cranial nerves III, IV, V1, and VI, causing ophthalmoplegia and ptosis due to impaired eye movement and sensory loss around the eye.
  • Superior orbital fissure: Triangular gap through which the middle cranial fossa connects with the orbit

Part

Structures Passing Through

Lateral Part
  • Lacrimal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve)
  • Frontal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve)
  • Trochlear nerve (CN IV)
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Meningeal branch of lacrimal artery
  • Anastomotic branch of middle meningeal artery (anastomoses with recurrent branch of lacrimal artery)

Middle Part
  • Upper division of oculomotor nerve (CN III)
  • Lower division of oculomotor nerve (CN III)
  • Nasociliary nerve
  • Abducens nerve (CN VI)

Medial Part
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
  • Sympathetic nerve from plexus around internal carotid artery

 

V2 (maxillary nerve) and II (optic nerve) (Option B, C, D) do not pass through the superior orbital fissure:

  • V2 passes through the foramen rotundum.
  • II passes through the optic canal.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man wakes up after sleeping with his arm draped over a chair and complains of pain. Which of the following accurately describes the order of susceptibility of nerve fibers in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A > B > C

Explanation:

The order of nerve fiber susceptibility to compression is: A > B > C

Susceptibility to

Local Anesthesia

Pressure

Hypoxia

Aγ and Aδ >> Aα and Aβ >> B >> C

Aα > B > C

B > A > C

questions.text: The artery that is palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Posterior tibial artery:

Explanation:

  • The posterior tibial artery runs posterior to the medial malleolus, between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal (Achilles) tendon.
  • It is commonly palpated at this location to assess peripheral circulation, especially in conditions like peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

Arrangement of Structures Under the Flexor Retinaculum (Medial to Lateral)

Mnemonic: Tom Dick ANd Harry

  • T: Tibialis posterior
  • D: Flexor Digitorum longus
  • A: Posterior tibial Artery
  • N: Tibial Nerve
  • H: Flexor Hallucis longus


Incorrect Options:

  • Anterior tibial artery (Option A): The anterior tibial artery is located on the anterior aspect of the leg, and it travels through the anterior compartment. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus (inner ankle) and the calcaneal tendon (Achilles tendon).
  • Dorsalis pedis artery (Option C): The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the dorsal (top) aspect of the foot, specifically between the first and second metatarsal bones. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon.
  • Popliteal artery (Option D): The popliteal artery is located behind the knee joint in the popliteal fossa. It is not palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon.

questions.text: After the parotidectomy operation, a patient presents with excessive sweating and redness over the parotid region. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A  - Frey’s Syndrome:

Explanation:

  • Frey’s syndrome (also called gustatory sweating) occurs when a patient sweats and flushes over the parotid (preauricular) region during eating or thinking about food.

Mechanism after parotidectomy:

  • During surgery, the auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, CN V3) is often injured.
  • This nerve carries parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and sympathetic fibres to sweat glands.
  • After nerve injury, aberrant regeneration occurs:
    • Parasympathetic fibres (originally meant for salivary secretion) regrow and mistakenly connect to sweat glands of the overlying skin.
    • When eating stimulates salivation, these sweat glands are also activated, causing redness and sweating in that region.

Incorrect Options:

  • Horner’s syndrome (Option B): Triad: Ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis (loss of sweating) on the same side of the face due to sympathetic pathway lesion. Here, sweating is increased, not decreased, and there’s no mention of eye signs.
  • Bell’s palsy (Option C): Lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy: unilateral facial muscle weakness, inability to close the eye, drooping mouth. No sweating/redness triggered by eating.
  • Glossopharyngeal neuralgia (Option D): Severe paroxysmal pain in the throat, tonsillar fossa, and ear due to CN IX irritation. Pain, not sweating, is the main feature.

questions.text: A woman from Delhi travels to Ladakh, a high-altitude region. Soon after arrival, she develops symptoms such as breathlessness, headache, and lightheadedness. What is the primary underlying mechanism responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Respiratory alkalosis:

Explanation:

At high altitude, low oxygen levels trigger hyperventilation, leading to CO₂ loss and increased blood pH, resulting in respiratory alkalosis.

Changes during Acclimatization

Respiratory
  • At high altitudes, lower oxygen levels stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors, increasing pulmonary ventilation.
  • This leads to enhanced CO2 removal, causing respiratory alkalosis. (Option C)
  • Kidneys respond by excreting more bicarbonate to stabilize blood pH, causing a sustained increase in ventilation and supporting prolonged acclimatization.

Haematological
  • At high altitudes, lower PO2 boosts erythropoietin production, increasing red blood cell count.
  • This also raises 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) levels in red blood cells.
  • Initially, alkalosis shifts the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the left but increased 2,3-DPG shifts it to the right, improving oxygen release to tissues.

Cardiovascular

  • Hypoxia activates the sympathoadrenal axis, increasing heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure.
  • Increased cardiac output leads to an increase in blood flow, and hypoxia causes vasodilation in the systemic circulation, further contributing to increased blood flow and oxygen supply to the tissues.

Tissue
  • In acclimatization, skeletal muscles undergo several changes, including an increase in the number of capillaries and mitochondria and an increase in myoglobin content.
  • Further, chemicals released from the hypoxic tissues stimulate angiogenesis.

Incorrect Options:

Respiratory acidosis (Option A) is seen in hypoventilation, not high altitude..

Metabolic alkalosis (Option B) is usually due to vomiting, diuretics, or excess alkali intake.

Metabolic acidosis (Option D) occurs in conditions like diarrhea, renal failure, or lactic acidosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple colonic polyps and has been diagnosed with colorectal carcinoma. There is a strong family history of Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). Which DNA repair mechanism is most likely defective in this condition ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mismatch repair:

Explanation:

  • A patient with multiple colonic polyps, colorectal carcinoma, and a family history of HNPCC most likely has a defect in the DNA mismatch repair mechanism.

Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch syndrome:

  • Characterized by microsatellite instability.
  • The most common gene mutation associated with Lynch syndrome is in the human MutS homolog 2 (hMSH2) gene.
  • Defects in mismatch repair genes, particularly hMSH1 and hMSH2, lead to ineffective repair of DNA replication errors.
  • These gene defects are located on chromosome 2.
  • The inability to correct mismatches during DNA replication increases the risk of mutations, contributing to the development of colon cancer.

Incorrect Options:

  • Nucleotide excision repair (Option A) fixes bulky DNA damage like thymine dimers and is defective in xeroderma pigmentosum, not HNPCC.
  • Base excision repair (Option C) corrects small base lesions from oxidative damage and is not involved in HNPCC.
  • Double-strand break repair (Option D) handles major DNA breaks and is linked to BRCA mutations, not mismatch repair defects seen in HNPCC.

questions.text: In malignant hyperthermia, a genetic mutation in the ryanodine receptor (RYR1) leads to a life-threatening reaction to certain anesthetic agents. What is the primary ionic abnormality caused by this receptor defect?

choices.text: Increased sodium influx into the muscle cell
Increased potassium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Increased chloride efflux from the muscle cell
Increased calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Increased calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum:

Explanation:

Malignant Hyperthermia is a life-threatening genetic disorder triggered by anesthetic agents like halothane or succinylcholine, caused by mutations in the RYR1 gene that affect the ryanodine receptor in skeletal muscle.

  • Cause: Mutation in the RYR1 gene → defective ryanodine receptor in skeletal muscle.
  • Trigger: Exposure to volatile anesthetics (e.g., halothane) or succinylcholine.
  • Mechanism: Excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum → sustained muscle contraction and hypermetabolism. (Option D)
  • Symptoms:
    • Rapid increase in body temperature
    • Muscle rigidity
    • Tachycardia
    • Hypercapnia
    • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Complications: Acidosis, renal failure, death if untreated.

Incorrect Options:

Increased sodium influx into the muscle cell (Option A): Not the primary defect in malignant hyperthermia; sodium handling isn't directly affected by the RYR1 mutation.

Increased potassium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (Option B): Potassium is not actively stored or regulated in the sarcoplasmic reticulum in this context.

Increased chloride efflux from the muscle cell (Option C): Chloride channels help stabilize the resting membrane potential but are not involved in the pathogenesis of malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A man presents with high VLDL and chylomicrons, with eruptive xanthomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C  - Familial hypertriglyceridemia:

Explanation:

Elevated VLDL and chylomicrons with eruptive xanthomas indicate high triglycerides, characteristic of Familial Hypertriglyceridemia (Type IV Hyperlipoproteinemia), presenting with increased VLDL, raised triglycerides, and small yellowish skin papules.

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Lipid profile: Elevated VLDL and triglycerides
  • Pathophysiology: Overproduction or decreased clearance of VLDL
  • Clinical features:
    • Eruptive xanthomas (small yellow papules on skin)
    • Pancreatitis risk due to very high triglycerides
    • No significant increase in LDL cholesterol
  • Management: Lifestyle changes, fibrates, and omega-3 fatty acids

Incorrect Options:

  • Familial hyperlipidemia (Option A) is a broad term; not specific.
  • Familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (Type III) (Option B) shows elevated IDL and chylomicron remnants, often with tuberoeruptive xanthomas, not mainly VLDL.
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (Option D) mainly shows elevated LDL cholesterol, leading to tendon xanthomas, not high VLDL/chylomicrons.

questions.text: Which opportunistic pathogen demonstrates a “crushed ping pong ball appearance” on Gomori methenamine stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumocystis jirovecii

Explanation:

The opportunistic pathogen demonstrating a “crushed ping pong ball appearance” on Gomori methenamine stain is Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia causing bilateral infiltrates

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

 
  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
 
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option A):

  • Appearance: Tiny intracellular yeast (2–5 μm) within macrophages.
  • Stains: Best seen with Giemsa or PAS, also silver stains, but they appear as small oval bodies, not crushed ping pong balls.
  • Clues in history: Associated with bird/bat droppings (caves, chicken coops), the Mississippi & Ohio River valleys.

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option B):

  • Appearance: Round to oval yeast with a thick polysaccharide capsule.
  • Stains:
    • India ink - capsule appears as a clear halo.
    • Mucicarmine - capsule stains red.
  • Key feature: “Soap-bubble” lesions in the brain on MRI (cryptococcal meningitis).

Aspergillus fumigatus (Option D):

  • Appearance: Septate hyphae with acute-angle branching (~45°).
  • Stains: Silver stain highlights hyphae, but you see filamentous branching structures, not rounded cysts.
  • Clues: Causes allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergillomas (fungal balls), and invasive aspergillosis in neutropenic patients.

questions.text: Which antibody is the first to appear and acts fastest during a primary (first) immune response to an infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IgM

Explanation:

IgM is produced early by naïve B cells after first exposure to an antigen. It is a pentamer, so it has 10 antigen-binding sites, giving it very high avidity (strong total binding), which makes it effective even before affinity maturation occurs.
It activates the classical complement pathway efficiently, helping clear pathogens quickly.

IgG (Option B): Appears later in the primary response but dominates the secondary response due to memory B cells.
IgE (Option C): Mainly for allergic reactions and defense against parasites; not part of early general infection control.
IgA (Option D): Found in mucosal secretions (tears, saliva, breast milk) for local immunity; not the first systemic responder.

questions.text: Chocolate agar is primarily used for the isolation of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Haemophilus influenzae

Explanation:

The organism described in the question is Haemophilus influenzae.

  • Haemophilus influenzae requires both X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors for growth which is found in chocolate agar.
  • The type b capsular polysaccharide (polyribosylribitol phosphate or PRP) is the most virulent serotype, particularly in unvaccinated children under 5 years old, often causing invasive diseases like meningitis.

Clinical features:

  • Meningitis: Fever, irritability, neck stiffness
  • Other invasive diseases: Epiglottitis, pneumonia, septic arthritis
  • Nontypeable strains often cause mucosal infections like otitis media, sinusitis

Diagnosis:

  • CSF analysis in meningitis: elevated protein, low glucose, pleocytosis
  • Gram stain: small gram-negative coccobacilli
  • Culture on chocolate agar
  • Antigen detection tests (latex agglutination) for rapid diagnosis
  • PCR for definitive identification and serotyping

Treatment:

  • Empiric therapy: Third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime)
  • Alternative: Chloramphenicol (if cephalosporin allergy)
  • Duration: Usually 10 days for meningitis

Listeria monocytogenes (Option B): Grows on standard blood agar; doesn’t require X or V factors.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option C): Best grown on regular blood agar; requires enriched CO₂ but not heated RBCs.

E. coli (Option D): While gram-negative, E. coli is a lactose fermenter on MacConkey agar, not chocolate agar. It is catalase-positive, but oxidase-negative.

questions.text: A breastfed infant presents with lethargy, hepatomegaly, and cataracts. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALPUT):

Explanation:

  • The infant’s lethargy, hepatomegaly, and cataracts after breastfeeding indicate classic galactosemia caused by Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency, leading to toxic buildup of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol, resulting in liver damage, cataracts, and neurological issues.

Classic Galactosemia

Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT) Deficiency

(Option B)
  • Severely deficient in individuals with Classic Galactosemia in which galactose-1-phosphate and, therefore, galactose accumulate.
  • It Is an inborn error of metabolism

Accumulation
  • Accumulated galactose is shunted into side pathways like galactitol production. Aldose reductase catalyzes it.
  • Galactose-1 phosphate accumulates in the liver, inhibiting galactokinase and glycogen phosphorylase, leading to hypoglycemia.

Bilirubin

Reduced bilirubin uptake and conjugation, increasing unconjugated bilirubin in blood

Symptoms

  1. Hypoglycemia, Hypophosphatemia, Hyperuricemia, Lactic acidosis
  2. Hepatomegaly, Jaundice,
  3. Severe mental retardation
  4. Galactosuria (galactose excreted in urine)
  5. Cataracts from dulcitol accumulation in the lens
  6. Tubular damage and generalized aminoaciduria

Diagnosis

  • Clinical manifestations (e.g., congenital cataract), presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels
  • Prenatal diagnosis via amniocentesis
  • Detection of heterozygous parents by elevated galactose levels after a galactose load

Complications in untreated cases

  • E. coli sepsis,
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Feeding problems,
  • Failure to thrive,
  • Hepatocellular damage,
  • Bleeding

Treatment

Withdrawal of galactose and lactose from the diet.

GALT deficiency is a part of the newborn screening panel

Incorrect Options:

  • Galactokinase (Option A) causes isolated cataracts but milder disease without severe liver involvement.
  • Aldolase B (Option C) causes hereditary fructose intolerance, presenting with hypoglycemia and liver problems after fructose ingestion.
  • Fructokinase (Option D) causes essential/fructosuria, a benign condition without serious symptoms.

questions.text: What is the primary protein that binds to thyroxine?
questions.solution:
Option C - Thyroxine-binding globulin:

Explanation:

  • Thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) are thyroid hormones transported in the blood bound to carrier proteins. These carrier proteins ensure the hormones' solubility and regulate their availability to tissues.
  • TBG is the primary and most specific protein that binds to thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). It has a high affinity for thyroid hormones and is responsible for carrying the majority of T4 in the blood.

Incorrect Options:

Follistatin (Option A): Follistatin is not involved in thyroid hormone transport. It primarily binds to and inhibits activins, which are proteins involved in various biological processes.

Transthyretin (Option B): Transthyretin (TTR), also known as prealbumin, binds a smaller fraction of T4 compared to TBG. It plays a secondary role in thyroid hormone transport, particularly in the cerebrospinal fluid.

Transferrin (Option D): Transferrin is a transport protein for iron in the blood and is unrelated to thyroid hormone transport.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency can lead to lactic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Thiamine

Explanation:

  • Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is a cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase; its deficiency blocks pyruvate conversion to acetyl-CoA, causing excess pyruvate to convert into lactate and resulting in lactic acidosis, as seen in beri-beri and Wernicke’s encephalopathy.

Source

  • The Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine. Therefore, whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritive value than completely polished refined foods.
  • When the grains are polished, the aleurone layer is usually removed.

Deficiency

Dry beriberi:

  • CNS manifestations are more common
  • Pain, paresthesia and loss of reflexes
  • Peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbances

Wet beriberi:

  • Wet beriberi is characterized by cardiovascular symptoms such as breathlessness, palpitations, and peripheral oedema.
  • Distended neck veins observed
  • High output cardiac failure

Biochemical parameters

Thiamine deficiency affects the enzyme transketolase, which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway.

  • Measuring transketolase activity in red blood cells is a specific test for thiamine deficiency and can confirm the diagnosis.
  • Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances.

RDA

Recommended Daily Allowance of Thiamine is 1–1.5 mg/day.

Incorrect Options:

  • Riboflavin (vitamin B2) (Option B) is involved in electron transport chain but not directly linked to lactic acidosis.
  • Niacin (vitamin B3) (Option C) is precursor of NAD+/NADP+, deficiency causes pellagra.
  • Biotin (Option D) is cofactor for carboxylases, deficiency causes multiple carboxylase deficiency, but not typically lactic acidosis.

questions.text: Which among the following best describes ‘Neuropraxia’?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Intact axon; Damaged nerve sheath

Explanation:

Neuropraxia is the mildest nerve injury, involving temporary conduction block with intact axon and reversible damage to the myelin sheath.

Seddon’s classification of nerve injuries:

Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I)

(Option A)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • No neuroma and no degeneration.
  • Recovery is complete within 6 weeks.

Axonotmesis

(Grade II)

(Option B ruled out)

  • Axonal damage, connective tissue intact.
  • Neuroma in continuity.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Recovery can take up to months
  • Complete recovery may not occur.
  • Motor march present

Neurotmesis

(Grade III)

(Option C ruled out)

  • Complete nerve disruption.
  • End or side neuroma.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Spontaneous recovery never occurs.
  • Repair is required (poor recovery)

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the immortality of cancer cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Telomerase:

Explanation:

  • Telomerase maintains telomere length, preventing chromosome degradation.
  • Telomere shortening occurs with each cell division, contributing to cellular ageing and death.
  • However, telomerase extends telomeres, enabling indefinite division. In cancer cells, its overexpression promotes uncontrolled proliferation and immortality.

Incorrect Options:

  • Topoisomerase (Option B) is responsible for manipulating the structure of DNA by inducing and resolving DNA strand breaks.
  • Helicase (Option C) unwinds the DNA double helix, allowing other enzymes to access and replicate the DNA.
  • RNA polymerase (Option D) synthesises RNA from a DNA template during transcription, essential for gene expression and protein synthesis. While its dysregulation can occur in cancer, it is not directly linked to cancer cell immortality.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, anemia, and hepatomegaly. Hemoglobin electrophoresis reveals the presence of HbS. What will be the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hydroxyurea:

Explanation:

The presence of HbS confirms Sickle Cell Anemia, and hydroxyurea is the primary treatment as it boosts fetal hemoglobin (HbF) levels, reducing red blood cell sickling and related complications.

  • Cause: Mutation in β-globin gene → production of abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS).
  • Pathophysiology: HbS polymerizes under low oxygen → sickling of RBCs → vaso-occlusion and hemolysis.
  • Symptoms: Anemia, fatigue, pain crises, splenomegaly/hepatomegaly, increased infection risk.
  • Diagnosis: Hemoglobin electrophoresis showing HbS.
  • Treatment:
    • Hydroxyurea: Increases fetal hemoglobin (HbF), reducing sickling episodes.
    • Blood transfusions for severe anemia/crisis.
    • Supportive care: pain management, infection prevention.

Incorrect Options:

  • Blood transfusion (Option B) may be used in severe cases but are not the first-line chronic therapy.
  • Iron supplementation (Option C) and Vitamin B12 supplementation (Option D) are not specific treatments for sickle cell anemia.

questions.text: A subject was brought to the Casualty with a history of RTA and head injury. On examination, he was conscious. When the doctor asked questions about the incident, his answers were irrelevant to the questions, but his speech was fluent. What could be the possible site of injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Superior temporal gyrus:

Explanation:

The Patient is conscious (rules out severe brainstem damage affecting consciousness), and has fluent speech (rules out Broca’s area lesion, which causes non-fluent speech). Since he gives Irrelevant answers, it indicates impaired comprehension rather than impaired production, pointing to Wernicke’s Aphasia located in the superior temporal gyrus (usually in the dominant hemisphere, left side).

Function of Wernicke’s area: Language comprehension (both spoken and written).

Lesion effect:

  • Speech is fluent (normal rate, rhythm, and articulation) but meaningless or irrelevant because the person cannot understand what’s being said.
  • This is called receptive aphasia (Wernicke’s aphasia).
  • Patients are often unaware of their speech mistakes.

Incorrect Options:

Precentral gyrus (Option A):

  • Location: Frontal lobe (primary motor cortex).
  • Function: Voluntary motor control of the contralateral body.
  • Lesion: Causes weakness or paralysis, not language comprehension problems.

Inferior frontal gyrus (Option B):

  • Contains Broca’s area in the dominant hemisphere.
  • Function: Speech production (motor aspect of language).
  • Lesion: Non-fluent aphasia – patient has slow, effortful speech, but comprehension is relatively preserved.

Brain stem (Option D):

  • Controls basic life functions, cranial nerve nuclei, and motor/sensory tracts.
  • Lesions cause severe motor/sensory deficits, cranial nerve palsies, or altered consciousness,not isolated fluent aphasia.

questions.text: Tau protein inclusions are involved in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Alzheimer’s Disease

Explanation:

  • The fundamental abnormality in Alzheimer’s disease is the accumulation of two proteins (Aβ and tau) in specific brain regions in the form of plaques and tangles.

Morphology of Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Gross: Cortical atrophy (narrowed gyri and widened sulci) is predominant in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes.
  • Histology:

Plaques
  • Deposits of Aβ peptides in the neuropil.
  • They are of two types: Diffuse and neuritic (senile).
  • Neuritic plaques contain both Aβ 40 and Aβ 42.
  • Diffuse plaques are predominantly made up of Aβ 42 and seen in trisomy 21 patients.

Tangles
  • Aggregates of the microtubule-binding protein tau.
  • Demonstrated by silver (Bielschowsky) staining.
  • Commonly found in cortical neurons, especially in the entorhinal cortex, and in other sites such as pyramidal cells of the hippocampus, amygdala, basal forebrain, and raphe nuclei.

Hirano bodies
  • Intracellular eosinophilic inclusions are typically found in conditions like Alzheimer's disease and Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease. 

Granulovacuolar degeneration
  • Formation of small, clear vacuoles within the neurons.

 

Plaques

 

Neurofibrillary tangles

 

Hirano bodies

 

Granulovacuolar degeneration

Incorrect Options:

  • Huntington's Disease (Option B) is characterised by toxic gain-of-function of mutant huntingtin protein and neuronal loss in the striatum.
  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) (Option C) involves the degeneration of motor neurons, often linked to superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) mutations or TDP-43 protein inclusions.
  • CNS Lymphoma (Option D) is a type of brain tumour originating from lymphocytes (B cells) and is unrelated to tau protein.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a major intracellular antioxidant and helps in detoxifying reactive oxygen species?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A  - Glutathione

Explanation:

Glutathione is the primary intracellular antioxidant that neutralizes reactive oxygen species by donating electrons, detoxifying them, regenerating other antioxidants, and maintaining cellular redox balance.

  • Major intracellular antioxidant composed of glutamate, cysteine, and glycine. (Option A)
  • Function: Neutralizes reactive oxygen species (ROS) by donating electrons, converting ROS to less harmful compounds.(Option A)
  • Regeneration: Helps regenerate other antioxidants like vitamins C and E.
  • Role: Maintains cellular redox balance and protects against oxidative stress.
  • Other antioxidants:
    • Superoxide dismutase (SOD): Converts superoxide radicals to hydrogen peroxide. (Option C ruled out)
    • Catalase: Converts hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. (Option B ruled out)
    • Peroxidase: Breaks down peroxides using reducing agents like glutathione. (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is most commonly associated with familial cases of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - SOD1 gene mutation

Explanation:

Familial Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is primarily associated with mutations in the SOD1 gene, which cause a toxic gain-of-function leading to motor neuron degeneration.

  • Definition: Progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting motor neurons.
  • Genetics: Most commonly caused by mutations in the SOD1 (superoxide dismutase 1) gene.
  • Pathophysiology: SOD1 mutation leads to toxic gain-of-function, causing motor neuron death.
  • Clinical features: Muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations, spasticity, and eventual paralysis.
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant pattern in familial cases.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical signs plus genetic testing for SOD1 mutation.
  • Treatment: Mainly supportive; no cure currently available.

Incorrect Options:

  • The CFTR gene mutation (Option A) causes cystic fibrosis. CFTR encodes a chloride/bicarbonate channel in epithelial cells. Impaired chloride secretion → dehydrated, thick mucus → chronic pulmonary infection/inflammation, bronchiectasis; pancreatic exocrine insufficiency (steatorrhea, failure to thrive); male infertility from congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens; salty sweat (↑ Cl⁻).
  • The HTT gene mutation (Option C) causes Huntington’s disease. Expansion of CAG trinucleotide repeats in the HTT gene → polyglutamine (polyQ) toxic gain-of-function.
  • The FMR1 gene mutation (Option D) causes Fragile X syndrome, which has CGG repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene. The most common inherited cause of intellectual disability; autistic traits, developmental delay, long face, large ears, macroorchidism, and connective-tissue laxity.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and poor concentration. The mother reports that the child has been eating non-food items such as chalk and soil for the past few months. A peripheral blood smear image shows microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Iron deficiency anemia

Explanation:

Pica, characterized by eating non-food items such as chalk and soil, is commonly linked to Iron Deficiency Anemia, which is supported by a peripheral smear showing microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells.

  • Cause: Inadequate iron leading to decreased hemoglobin synthesis.
  • Common in: Children, pregnant women, and individuals with chronic blood loss.
  • Symptoms: Fatigue, pallor, poor concentration, and pica (craving/eating non-food substances like soil or chalk).
  • Peripheral smear: Microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells.
  • Diagnosis: Low serum ferritin, low serum iron, increased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC).
  • Treatment: Oral iron supplementation and addressing the underlying cause.

Incorrect Options:

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option A) causes macrocytic anemia, not microcytic.
  • Thalassemia major (Option C) causes microcytic anemia but usually presents earlier and more severely, with different clinical features.
  • Lead poisoning (Option D) can cause anemia but typically has basophilic stippling on smear and neurological symptoms.

questions.text: For testing blood clotting/ coagulation parameters, blood is collected in which color-coded vacutainer tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Blue

Explanation:

The light blue Vacutainer contains sodium citrate as an anticoagulant and is specifically used for coagulation studies, such as Prothrombin Time (PT) and Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT). The anticoagulant preserves the coagulation factors for accurate testing.

Colour

Anti-coagulants

Uses

Purple/Lavender

EDTA (Ca2+ chelating anticoagulant)

CBC, Peripheral Smear, ESR, HbA1c

Light Blue (Option B)

Citrate (Ca2+ chelating anticoagulant)

ESR, PT, aPTT

Red (Option A)

No anti-coagulant is added

Serum studies (Proteins, enzymes, hormones)

Yellow

Clot activator/Gel separator

Serum studies (Proteins, enzymes, hormones)

Grey (Option D)

Sodium Fluoride

Blood Glucose

Green (Option B)

Heparin

ABG, Osmotic fragility, flow cytometry, immunophenotyping

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic with abdominal pain, irritability, and developmental delay. On examination, the child has pallor and a bluish line on the gums. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic anemia, and a peripheral blood smear shows red blood cells with basophilic stippling. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lead poisoning

Explanation:

  • Classic signs of Lead Poisoning include abdominal pain, irritability, developmental delay, pallor, and a bluish line on the gums ( Burtonian’s or Burton’s line), along with laboratory findings of microcytic anemia and basophilic stippling on the peripheral smear.

Source

Exposure to lead from paint, contaminated soil, or old pipes.

Enzymes inhibited
  • Ferrochelatase
  • ALA-dehydratase
  • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase).

Clinical features
  • Facial pallor: Circumoral (vasospasm) → Earliest and most specific feature
  • Lead line or Burtonian lines: Stippled blue line observed on the gums, resulting from a subepithelial deposit of granules.

 

 

  • Lead osteopathy/Lead line (Bone-line): Calcium deposition occurs at the growth plates of bones (specifically the lower end of the femur and the upper end of the tibia).
  • Lead palsy: Predominantly motor features → (dry belly ache, wrist drop - radial nerve), foot drop - common peroneal nerve).
  • Blood picture: Microcytic-hypochromic anemia, Cabot rings in RBCs, Sideroblasts (nucleated red cells), Anisocytosis, Poikilocytosis, Polycythemia
  • Basophilic stippling or Punctate basophilia

 ​​​​​​​

  • Colic and constipation (Painter's Colic or Devonshire colic) → Spasmodic pain relieved by pressure (at night).
  • Saturnine gout (due to decreased excretion of uric acid)
  • Encephalopathy
  • Reproductive system (amenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, abortion, sterility derangments)
  • CVS and Kidney (Hypertension, arteriolar degeneration, nephritis).

Treatment

Remove lead exposure and chelation therapy (e.g., EDTA, dimercaprol).

Incorrect Options:

  • Iron deficiency anemia (Option A) does not present with basophilic stippling or Burton’s line.
  • Sideroblastic anemia (Option B) shows ring sideroblasts in bone marrow but not Burton’s line or neurological symptoms.
  • Thalassemia minor (Option D) has microcytic anemia but lacks lead poisoning features.

questions.text: Which of the following is pro-apoptotic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Bax:

Explanation:

The correct answer is Bax, because it is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 protein family.

  • The Bcl-2 family regulates the intrinsic (mitochondrial) apoptosis pathway.
  • Members are divided into:
    • Anti-apoptotic: Bcl-2, Bcl-xL, Mcl-1 → preserve mitochondrial membrane integrity, prevent cytochrome c release.
    • Pro-apoptotic: Bax, Bak, Bok → promote mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilisation (MOMP), allowing cytochrome c release and caspase activation.

Mnemonic:

  • "Bax and Bak Break" (break the mitochondrial membrane) → pro-apoptotic.
  • "Bcl and Bcl-xL Build" (preserve the membrane) → anti-apoptotic.

questions.text: In a village of Assam, a man is observed walking with the help of a stick and has genu valgum. Many people in the same village present with similar symptoms. What is the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Skeletal fluorosis

Explanation:

The presence of genu valgum and multiple affected individuals in an Assam village suggests Skeletal Fluorosis, a condition common in areas with high fluoride levels in drinking water, leading to bone pain, stiffness, joint deformities, and walking difficulty.

  • Cause: Chronic ingestion of high levels of fluoride, usually through drinking water.
  • Endemic Areas: Common in parts of India, especially Assam, Andhra Pradesh, and Rajasthan.
  • Symptoms:
    • Bone pain and joint stiffness
    • Genu valgum (knock knees), difficulty walking
    • May progress to crippling deformities
  • X-ray findings: Increased bone density (osteosclerosis)
  • Prevention: Use of fluoride-free water, defluoridation techniques
  • Treatment: Primarily supportive; address deformities and improve nutrition.

Fluorine content in water

Related symptoms

<0.5mg/L

Dental caries

>1.5mg/L

Dental fluorosis

3-6mg/L

Skeletal fluorosis

>10mg/L

Crippling fluorosis

Incorrect Options:

  • Calcium deficiency (Option A) and Vitamin D deficiency (Osteomalacia) (Option D) cause bone pain and weakness, but are less likely to occur in clusters.
  • Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) (Option B) affects collagen synthesis and presents with bleeding gums, petechiae, not typically genu valgum.

questions.text: A young boy presents with joint swelling after a fall. Lab investigations show normal PT and raised aPTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Haemophilia:

Explanation:

This presentation matches haemophilia because:

  • Joint swelling after trauma → suggests hemarthrosis, which is typical of coagulation factor deficiencies, especially haemophilia.

  • Normal PT → extrinsic pathway is intact.

  • Prolonged aPTT → intrinsic pathway defect (Factors VIII, IX, XI).

  • Haemophilia A = Factor VIII deficiency; Haemophilia B = Factor IX deficiency.

Incorrect Options:

Von Willebrand Disease (Option A): usually has prolonged aPTT (due to low factor VIII) and mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, menorrhagia), not deep joint bleeds as the main feature.

Iron Deficiency Anaemia (IDA) (Option C): causes pallor and fatigue, not isolated coagulation abnormalities.

Platelet function disorder (Option D): causes mucosal bleeding and petechiae, not hemarthrosis; PT and aPTT are usually normal.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with tremors, difficulty in speech, and behavioral changes. On examination, he has hepatomegaly and a golden-brown ring at the limbus of the cornea (Kayser-Fleischer ring). Wilson’s disease is suspected. Which of the following is the best investigation to support the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Liver biopsy for copper estimation

Explanation:

  • Wilson’s Disease is characterized by excessive copper accumulation, particularly in the liver and brain, and the gold standard for diagnosis is a liver biopsy with quantitative copper estimation.

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Gene

Mutation in ATP7B gene (chromosome 13)

Defect

Impaired copper excretion into bile → copper accumulation in liver, brain, cornea

Clinical features

Hepatic: Hepatitis, hepatomegaly, cirrhosis

Neurological: Tremors, dysarthria, dystonia, parkinsonism

Psychiatric: Behavioural changes, personality disorders

Ocular: Kayser-Fleischer rings (golden-brown ring at corneal limbus)

Diagnosis

↓ Serum ceruloplasmin (Option A ruled out)

↑ 24-hour urinary copper excretion (Option D ruled out)

↑ Hepatic copper on liver biopsy (gold standard) (Option B)

MRI brain: Panda sign (in severe cases)

Management

Chelation therapy: Penicillamine or Trientine

Zinc supplements: Inhibit copper absorption

Liver transplant: In fulminant hepatic failure


Serum copper (Option C) is usually low, since most copper is ceruloplasmin-bound.

questions.text: What is the status of the marked individual?

choices.text: Has a disease of chronic origin

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Adopted from another family:

Explanation:

  • In standard pedigree notation:
    • An individual marked with brackets around the symbol indicates adoption.
    • If the brackets are dashed, it usually means adopted in (from another family).
    • If the brackets are solid, it usually means adopted out (given to another family).

  • Has a disease of chronic origin / Curable disease (Option B, C): would be indicated by shading or other symbols, not brackets.
  • Twin (Option D): represented by two siblings connected by a triangle or horizontal bar, not brackets.

questions.text: A family consumes a diet predominantly of rice and pulses developed signs of muscle weakness and movement. Which of the following should be given for prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Thiamine

Explanation:

The given case scenario of family that consumes a diet predominantly consisting of rice and pulses causing muscle weakness points to Dry beri-beri caused by deficiency of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine).

  • Beriberi is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcoholism and diets lacking in unpolished grains.
  • The Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine. Therefore, whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritive value than completely polished refined foods.
  • When the grains are polished, the aleurone layer is usually removed.

Deficiency:

Dry beriberi:

  • CNS manifestations are more common
  • Pain, paresthesia and loss of reflexes
  • Peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbances

Wet beriberi:

  • Wet beriberi is characterized by cardiovascular symptoms such as breathlessness, palpitations, and peripheral oedema.
  • Distended neck veins observed
  • High output cardiac failure

Biochemical parameters:

  • Thiamine deficiency affects the enzyme transketolase, which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway.
    • Measuring transketolase activity in red blood cells is a specific test for thiamine deficiency and can confirm the diagnosis.
    • Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances.
  • Recommended Daily Allowance of Thiamine is 1–1.5 mg/day.

Treatment:

  • In acute thiamine deficiency with either cardiovascular or neurologic signs, 200 mg of thiamine three times daily should be given intravenously until there is no further improvement in acute symptoms; oral thiamine (10 mg/d) should subsequently be given until recovery is complete.

Incorrect Options:

Calcium (Option A):

  • Needed for bone health, muscle contraction, and nerve conduction.
  • Deficiency causes osteoporosis, rickets (in children), tetany, but not the neuropathy seen in dry beriberi.
  • Rice-based diets may be low in calcium, but the described neurological weakness is more consistent with B1 deficiency.

Vitamin D (Option C):

  • Regulates calcium/phosphate metabolism.
  • Deficiency → rickets in children, osteomalacia in adults.
  • Presents with bone pain, deformities, and muscle weakness due to hypocalcemia, but not peripheral neuropathy.

Iron (Option D):

  • Deficiency → microcytic, hypochromic anaemia (fatigue, pallor, pica).
  • No direct link to the described nerve-related muscle weakness pattern.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with lethargy, vomiting, and poor feeding. The episode occurred after prolonged fasting. Laboratory results reveal hypoglycemia, low ketone levels (hypoketosis), and mild hepatomegaly. These findings suggest a defect in fat metabolism. Which of the following is the most likely underlying disorder?

choices.text: Glycogen storage disease type I (Von Gierke disease)

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency

Explanation:

This presentation is classic for medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency, a fatty acid β-oxidation defect.

  • Prolonged fasting - Body normally switches to fatty acid oxidation for energy and ketone production.
  • MCAD deficiency - Inability to break down medium-chain fatty acids → impaired ketogenesis and gluconeogenesis.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Hypoglycemia (due to no gluconeogenesis from fat-derived acetyl-CoA)
    • Hypoketosis (unbale to synthesize ketone bodies from fatty acids)
    • Mild hepatomegaly (fat accumulation in liver)
  • Typical age: Symptoms often appear between 3–24 months, especially after illness or prolonged fasting.

Incorrect Options:

  • Her’s disease (GSD type VI) (Option A): Liver phosphorylase deficiency → fasting hypoglycemia + hepatomegaly, but ketones are normal because fat oxidation is intact.
  • Hereditary fructose intolerance (Option C): Aldolase B deficiency → symptoms after fructose ingestion, not prolonged fasting; causes hypoglycemia, vomiting, jaundice.
  • GSD type I (Von Gierke disease) (Option D): Severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia, but normal or high ketones.

questions.text:
Which CD markers are typically positive in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL)?

.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CD19, CD20, CD23, CD5:

Explanation:

In Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL), the hallmark immunophenotype is:

  • B-cell markers: CD19, CD20, CD23
  • Aberrant co-expression of T-cell marker: CD5 (this is unusual for B-cells and is a diagnostic clue)
  • CLL is a mature B-cell neoplasm → expresses typical B-cell surface antigens (CD19, CD20, CD23).
  • Uniquely, it abnormally expresses CD5, which is normally a T-cell marker, this feature helps distinguish CLL from other B-cell leukemias/lymphomas.

Incorrect Options:

CD3, CD5, CD8 (Option A): T-cell markers (CD8 = cytotoxic T cells), not CLL.

CD10, CD19, CD22 (Option B): seen in precursor B-cell ALL (CD10 - CALLA antigen), not mature CLL.

CD13, CD33, CD117 (Option D): myeloid lineage markers (seen in AML), not lymphoid.

questions.text: 2-year-old with fever, lymphadenopathy and H&E has hallmark cells. The diagnosis of anaplastic large cell lymphoma was made. Most likely translocation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - t(2;5):

Explanation:

Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma (ALCL) is most often associated with the t(2;5) translocation.

  • t(2;5) → creates the NPM-ALK fusion gene
    • NPM - nucleophosmin (chromosome 5)
    • ALK - anaplastic lymphoma kinase (chromosome 2)
  • This fusion leads to constitutive activation of ALK tyrosine kinase, driving uncontrolled cell growth.
  • ALCL histology shows hallmark cells, large pleomorphic cells with horseshoe- or kidney-shaped nuclei and abundant cytoplasm.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

  • t(8;14) (Option A): Seen in Burkitt lymphoma. MYC gene on chromosome 8 translocates to Ig heavy chain locus on chromosome 14 → MYC overexpression. It is a very aggressive B-cell lymphoma; common in children in malaria-endemic areas.
  • t(8;22) (Option B): Variant of Burkitt lymphoma involving MYC and Ig lambda light chain locus (chromosome 22).
  • t(14;18) (Option D): Seen in Follicular lymphoma. BCL2 gene (chromosome 18) translocates to Ig heavy chain locus (chromosome 14) → BCL2 overexpression → apoptosis inhibition. It usually has an indolent course.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with poor feeding, vomiting, and lethargy. Laboratory studies show hyperammonemia and elevated levels of orotic acid in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency

Explanation:

The infant's symptoms and laboratory findings are highly suggestive of Type 2 Hyperammonemia, or Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) Deficiency.

  • Hyperammonemia type 2 is an X-linked deficiency caused by a defect in ornithine transcarbamoylase (this reaction occurs in mitochondria), which forms citrulline in the Krebs cycle.
  • Mothers with this condition may have hyperammonemia and avoid high-protein foods.
  • Elevated blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine glutamine levels are due to increased glutamine synthesis in response to high ammonia levels.
  • Orotic aciduria- Due to the channelling of carbamoyl phosphate into pyrimidine synthesis.

Feature

Type 1 Hyperammonemia

Type 2 Hyperammonemia

Defective Enzyme

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS1) (Option A)

Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive

Mechanism

The inability to synthesize carbamoyl phosphate blocks the urea cycle.

Accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate in the mitochondria, which then spills over into the cytoplasm.

Metabolic Consequences
  • Elevated ammonia and glutamate
  • Normal orotic acid and uracil
  • Low citrulline.
  • Elevated ammonia, glutamate, and glutamine.
  • High uracil and/or orotic acid (excess carbamoyl phosphate enters pyrimidine synthesis).
  • Normal citrulline.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms coincide with increased protein intake.
  • CNS: Lethargy, drowsiness, coma, Convulsions, vomiting, respiratory stimulation, hyperventilation.
  • Similar to Type 1.
  • Hepatomegaly.

 

  • Orotidine 5'-phosphate decarboxylase deficiency (Option C): this is orotic aciduria (megaloblastic anaemia, growth retardation), but ammonia is normal.
  • Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency (Option D): causes hyperammonemia but with elevated citrulline/argininosuccinate, not orotic acid.

questions.text: In Barrett’s oesophagus, which of the following epithelial transformations occurs?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Squamous to intestinal columnar epithelium:

Explanation:

Barrett's oesophagus is a complication of chronic GERD, characterised by intestinal metaplasia (Option B) in the oesophageal squamous mucosa. It increases the risk of oesophageal adenocarcinoma.

  • Occurs in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD.
  • Affects up to 2% of the general population.
  • Most common in white males, typically between ages 40 and 60.
  • Cancer Risk:
    • Increases the risk of oesophageal adenocarcinoma.
    • The majority of oesophageal adenocarcinomas are associated with Barrett's oesophagus, but not all individuals with it will develop cancer.
  • Recognised as red, velvety mucosa (Barrett's mucosa) extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction & alternating with pale squamous mucosa and light-brown gastric mucosa.
  • Subclassified as long segment (≥3 cm) or short segment (<3 cm).
  • Short-segment disease carries a lower cancer risk compared to long-segment disease.

  • Intestinal-type metaplasia with goblet cells replacing squamous epithelium.
    • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett oesophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain blue with Alcian blue.
    • This imparts the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.

  • Goblet cells are diagnostic, with pale blue mucous vacuoles resembling a wine goblet.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, like gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present.

Incorrect Options:

Columnar to squamous (Option A): occurs in squamous metaplasia (e.g., chronic irritation in bronchi of smokers), not Barrett’s.

Transitional to squamous (Option C): occurs in the bladder with chronic irritation (e.g., schistosomiasis).

Cuboidal to columnar (Option D): not typical in Barrett’s; cuboidal epithelium is seen in small ducts/glands, not in the oesophagus.

questions.text: A child presents with abdominal distension and an enlarged liver by 8 cm below the costal margin. The liver is smooth on palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Glycogen Storage Disease (GSD)

Explanation:

  • A child with abdominal distension and massive hepatomegaly (8 cm below the costal margin) points to a metabolic or infiltrative cause.
  • Smooth liver suggests uniform enlargement without focal mass or nodularity.
  • In GSD (e.g., Von Gierke disease, Pompe, Cori, Anderson), hepatomegaly results from excessive glycogen accumulation in hepatocytes.
  • Often presents in infancy/early childhood with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia (depending on subtype), but in some types, the main clue is a large smooth liver.

Incorrect Options:

  • Lysosomal Storage Disease (LSD) (Option B): Also causes hepatomegaly, but often with coexisting splenomegaly, coarse facial features, and developmental regression (e.g., Gaucher, Niemann–Pick).
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (Option C): Rare in a young child without pre-existing liver disease; typically causes a firm, irregular nodular liver.
