  • Autoimmune hepatitis (Option D): Usually causes mild to moderate hepatomegaly with jaundice, fatigue, elevated transaminases; not massive smooth enlargement.

questions.text: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by a defect in which of the following platelet glycoproteins?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - GpIb/IX complex:

Explanation:

Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by a defect in the GpIb/IX complex on platelets.

  • GpIb/IX complex is the receptor for von Willebrand factor (vWF) → mediates platelet adhesion to subendothelial collagen after vascular injury.
  • In Bernard–Soulier syndrome, this adhesion step is impaired → defective platelet plug formation.
  • Labs/Findings:
    • Normal or low platelet count
    • Prolonged bleeding time
    • Giant platelets on peripheral smear
    • Normal platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, epinephrine, but absent aggregation with ristocetin (not corrected by adding normal plasma, unlike vWD).

Incorrect Options:

GpIIb/IIIa (Option A):

  • Function: Binds fibrinogen → platelet aggregation.
  • Defect causes Glanzmann thrombasthenia, not BSS.
  • Lab: Normal platelet count, defective aggregation with all agonists except ristocetin.

GpIa/IIa (Option C):

  • Function: Binds collagen (supports platelet adhesion).
  • Defects are rare and cause mild bleeding disorders, not the classic BSS picture.

GpIV (Option D): Also called CD36; role in platelet adhesion and scavenger receptor function.

questions.text: Which of the following substances, at the given concentration, makes water unsuitable for human consumption according to safety standards?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cadmium - 0.3 mg/L

Explanation:

The unsafe substance here is cadmium at 0.3 mg/L, because it exceeds permissible limits for drinking water.

  • WHO & BIS (Bureau of Indian Standards) limits:
    • Fluoride: desirable ~1.0 mg/L (max 1.5 mg/L) → 0.8 mg/L is safe.
    • Cadmium: safe limit is 0.003 mg/L (3 µg/L) → 0.3 mg/L is 100× higher, toxic.
    • Chloride: permissible up to 250 mg/L → 200 mg/L is safe.
    • Calcium: desirable up to 75 mg/L (max 200 mg/L) → 7 mg/L is safe.

Toxicity of cadmium in water:

  • Chronic exposure → kidney damage (proximal tubular dysfunction), bone demineralisation (Itai-Itai disease in Japan), carcinogenic effects.
  • Often from industrial waste, batteries, and electroplating runoff.

questions.text: A patient with renal disease undergoes a biopsy. On Congo red staining, the deposits show apple-green birefringence under polarised light. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Amyloidosis:

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a patient with renal disease undergoing a biopsy and on Congo red staining, the deposits showing apple-green birefringence under polarized light points towards a diagnosis of AA amyloidosis, where chronic inflammation leads to the production of SAA, resulting in amyloid deposition in various organs.

The most appropriate staining technique for confirming the diagnosis in this patient is by Congo red stain.

Investigations in amyloidosis:

  • The diagnosis depends on the histologic demonstration of amyloid deposits in tissues.
  • The most common sites biopsied are the kidney when renal manifestations are present or rectal or gingival tissues in patients suspected of having systemic amyloidosis.
  • Examination of abdominal fat aspirates stained with Congo red can also be used for the diagnosis of systemic amyloidosis.
  • Staining:

Stains/technique

Appearance

Congo red
  • Most widely used and specific.
  • Light microscopy: Salmon pink/red stains.
  • Polarizing microscopy: Apple-green birefringence.

H & E
  • Eosin & hematoxylin staining on light microscopy.
  • Amorphous, eosinophilic, extracellular substance.

Thioflavin T
  • Fluorescent stain.
  • Yellow color under UV light.

Electron microscopy
  • Non-branching fibrils of indefinite length.
  • Diameter: 7.5-10 nm.

X-ray crystallography & infrared spectroscopy
  • Cross-β-pleated sheet conformation.

Methyl violet

Crystal violet

PAS
  • Amyloid positive.
  • Abdominal fat aspiration is preferred over rectal biopsy.
  • In suspected cases of AL amyloidosis, serum and urine protein electrophoresis and immunoelectrophoresis should be performed.
  • Bone marrow aspirates in such cases often show monoclonal plasmacytosis, even in the absence of overt multiple myeloma.
  • Scintigraphy with radiolabeled serum amyloid P component is a rapid and specific test since it binds to the amyloid deposits and reveals their presence.
  • It also gives a measure of the extent of amyloidosis and can be used to follow patients undergoing treatment.
  • The given images below show Congo red staining in amyloidosis.

Incorrect Options:

Minimal change disease (Option B): normal light microscopy; EM shows foot process effacement; Congo red negative.

Diabetic nephropathy (Option C): nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel–Wilson lesions); no Congo red positivity.

Membranous nephropathy (Option D): thickened GBM and subepithelial immune deposits; Congo red negative.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with palpitations, tremors, dry mouth, heart rate 130 bpm, respiratory rate 34/min. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D  - TCA

Explanation:

  • The combination of tachycardia, tremor and anticholinergic sign (dry mouth) suggests an anticholinergic / sympathomimetic toxidrome, which is consistent with tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity
  • Manifestations are:
    • Excitement. delirium and other anticholinergic symptoms as seen in atropine poisoning, followed by muscle spasms, convulsions and coma.
    • Respiration is depressed, body temperature may fall, BP is low, and tachycardia is prominent.
    • ECG changes and ventricular arrhythmias are common.

Treatment:

  • Primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.
  • Acidosis must be corrected by bicarbonate infusion.
  • Diazepam may be injected i.v. to control convulsions and delirium.
  • Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/ lidocaine may be used.
    • The class IA and IC antiarrhythmics and digoxin themselves depress cardiac conduction; are therefore contraindicated.

Incorrect Options:

  • Lithium (Option A): Can cause tremor but not the anticholinergic dry mouth and marked tachycardia.
  • Opioid (Option B): Causes miosis, sedation and respiratory depression, not tachycardia and dry mouth.
  • Propranolol (Option C): A beta-blocker - would lower heart rate, not cause tachycardia.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male presents with symptoms of stress and inability to manage work-life balance. On evaluation, his blood pressure is found to be 150/95 mmHg and and elevated blood sugar. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Advise rest only, no pharmacological treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Start telmisartan:

Explanation:

  • This patient has stage 2 hypertension (≥140/90 mmHg) along with hyperglycemia, suggesting increased cardiovascular and metabolic risk.
  • Telmisartan, an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), is preferred in this scenario because:
    • It lowers BP by reducing peripheral vascular resistance.
    • Provides renal protection by reducing intraglomerular pressure.
    • Does not worsen glucose metabolism (unlike some diuretics or beta-blockers).
    • Evidence suggests ARBs may improve insulin sensitivity.

Incorrect Options:

  • Start glucocorticoids (Option A): Contraindicated here - would worsen both blood pressure and blood sugar.
  • Start thiazide diuretic (Option C): While effective for BP, can cause hyperglycemia and adverse metabolic effects, so not ideal in someone with elevated sugars.
  • Advise rest only (Option D): Non-pharmacologic therapy alone is insufficient for stage 2 hypertension; immediate pharmacologic therapy is indicated alongside lifestyle changes.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease presents with severe anemia. Laboratory tests reveal normocytic, normochromic anemia. What is the most appropriate treatment to manage this patient’s anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Darbepoetin alfa

Explanation:

  • Anemia of chronic kidney disease is primarily due to erythropoietin deficiency from the diseased kidney; treatment uses erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (e.g., epoetin alfa or darbepoetin alfa) to correct anemia.
  • Iron status should be checked and corrected if iron-deficient, but the core therapy for CKD-related normocytic anemia is ESA.

Incorrect Options:

  • Folic acid (Option A) and Vitamin B12 (Option B): Indicated for megaloblastic (macrocytic) anemia due to deficiencies - not the typical CKD anemia.
  • Iron chelation (Option D): Used for iron overload, not for CKD anemia.

questions.text: A 75 kg person is administered a drug with a half-life of 3 hours. What is the approximate clearance of the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 23 mL/min

Explanation:

  • Clearance:

 

  • Here Vd = 100 mL/kg = 100 × 70kg = 7000 mL
  • Cl = 0.693 × 7000/ 3hr = 1617 ml/hr ~ 23 mL/min

questions.text: Which medication can be administered to reduce the frequency of future headache episodes in a 26-year-old female patient who experiences one-sided pulsating headaches accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and finds relief in a dimly lit environment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A  - Propranolol

Explanation:

  • The clinical history indicates a migraine headache. Propranolol is commonly used for migraine prophylaxis, with effects typically observed within 4 weeks and sustained with prolonged therapy.

Use of propranolol

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis
  • Essential tremors
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improve cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

 

Acute management of migraine attack

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan.
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide
  • Opioids and NSAIDs

Prophylaxis of migraine

  • Propranolol (Beta-blocker, DOC for migraine prophylaxis).
  • Flunarizine (Calcium channel blocker)
  • Cyproheptadine: (Antihistamine that can help alleviate migraine symptoms).
  • Candesartan: (Angiotensin II receptor blocker).
  • Clonidine
  • Pizotifen (Serotonin antagonist that can help reduce migraine frequency).
  • Gabapentin, valproate, nortriptyline, and topiramate are medications that can help manage migraine symptoms by releasing the neurotransmitter GABA.
  • Topiramate
  • Methysergide (Manages migraine symptoms by blocking serotonin receptors).

Incorrect Options: 

  • Alprazolam (Option B) and Diazepam (Option C) are benzodiazepines that can be used in acute attacks of migraine by inducing sleep in the patient.
  • Fluoxetine (Option D) is an SSRI that may help treat migraine in some people.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of excessive thirst and increased urination of around 6–7 liters per day. He had a history of cerebral trauma one month ago. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Desmopressin

Explanation:

  • Post-traumatic central diabetes insipidus (CDI) results from decreased secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH/vasopressin) from the posterior pituitary, often following head injury or neurosurgical procedures. This leads to inability to concentrate urine, causing polyuria, polydipsia, and hypernatremia.
  • Desmopressin (DDAVP) is a synthetic vasopressin analog with high affinity for V2 receptors in the kidney, promoting water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, thereby correcting polyuria and polydipsia.
  • It is the first-line treatment for CDI.

Incorrect Options:

  • Hydrochlorothiazide (Option A): Thiazide diuretics reduce urine output in nephrogenic DI by causing mild volume contraction, which increases proximal tubular water reabsorption, but they are not first-line for central DI.
  • Tolvaptan (Option C): A selective V2 receptor antagonist used for hyponatremia due to SIADH or hypervolemic states (e.g., heart failure, cirrhosis), not for DI.
  • Insulin (Option D): Used in diabetes mellitus for glycemic control, unrelated to DI.

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents with arthritis and develops carditis. Which of the following is the most appropriate anti-inflammatory drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Celecoxib

Explanation:

  • In patients with rheumatic fever or other inflammatory conditions requiring NSAID therapy, a history of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) significantly increases the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and ulcer recurrence with traditional nonselective NSAIDs.
  • Celecoxib is a COX-2 selective inhibitor that provides effective anti-inflammatory action while sparing COX-1–mediated gastric mucosal protection, thus reducing (but not eliminating) GI injury risk.
  • It is therefore the preferred NSAID in patients with high GI risk who still require anti-inflammatory therapy.

Incorrect Options:

  • Ibuprofen (Option A) and Diclofenac (Option B): Nonselective NSAIDs that inhibit both COX-1 and COX-2, leading to increased gastric acid secretion and reduced mucosal protection - dangerous in patients with PUD.
  • Naloxone (Option C): An opioid antagonist used for opioid overdose reversal; has no role as an anti-inflammatory agent.

questions.text: A patient with known rheumatic heart disease is now found to have a 1–2 cm aneurysm on imaging. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Aspirin lifelong

Explanation:

  • A 1–2 cm coronary artery aneurysm (10–20 mm) falls in the category of a large aneurysm, which significantly increases the risk of intraluminal thrombosis, distal embolization, and myocardial infarction.
  • Long-term antiplatelet therapy with low-dose aspirin is recommended to reduce thrombotic risk in such patients.
  • In the absence of active infection, acute thrombosis, or other complicating factors, lifelong aspirin remains the cornerstone of therapy.

Incorrect Options:

  • Aspirin + Clopidogrel (Option B): Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is used in acute coronary syndromes, stenting, or in certain high-risk giant aneurysms, but not routinely for stable large aneurysms without acute events.
  • Aspirin for 3 weeks (Option C): This short course is inadequate for an aneurysm of this size because thrombotic risk persists long-term.
  • IV antibiotics (Option D): Indicated for infective endocarditis or infected aneurysms; not required here as there are no signs of infection.

questions.text: A man was abducted from his home, and his son subsequently claimed rights to his father’s property. As per Section 111 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA), until when is the son not entitled to claim inheritance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. 7 years

Explanation:

  • Section 111 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA) states that a person who has been missing and not heard of for 7 years by those who would naturally have heard from them is presumed dead. Until those 7 years are completed, legal heirs cannot claim inheritance. The burden of proving the fact of the missing lies on the person claiming the benefit of this presumption. For 7 years, property rights remain with the missing person’s estate, and heirs cannot take possession.

Incorrect Options:

5 years (Option A): No legal presumption of death at 5 years; heirs cannot claim property before the statutory period.

6 years (Option B): Falls short of the legal requirement; property rights remain frozen until 7 years.

10 years (Option D): Longer than required by law; Section 111 specifically sets the period at 7 years, not 10.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct triple drug regimen for the treatment of Helicobacter pylori infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Omeprazole + Clarithromycin + Metronidazole

Explanation:

  • H. pylori eradication is essential in the management of peptic ulcer disease (PUD)
  • The most common treatment regimens include combinations of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) with antibiotics.

1. Triple therapy:

  • PPI for 4-6 weeks, Clarithromycin + Metronidazole (> Amoxicillin) for 2 weeks.

2. Quadruple therapy:

  • PPI
  • Bismuth (Disadvantage: Blackish discoloration of the tongue)
  • Tetracyclines
  • Metronidazole

3. Hybrid therapy

  • For the patients who cannot tolerate two antibiotics at a time.
  • PPI + Amoxicillin for 7 days o PPI + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin + Nitroimidazole × 7 days.

4. LOAD

  • In patients with macrolides-based resistance.
  • Levofloxacin + Omeprazole + Alinia (Nitazoxanide) + Doxycycline.

questions.text: A patient with asthma on inhaled corticosteroids and LABA continues to have exacerbations. FEV1 is normal, and there is no improvement with salbutamol challenge. The symptoms worsen seasonally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Increase dose of ICS

Explanation:

  • This patient is uncontrolled on low- or moderate-dose ICS + LABA.
  • According to GINA stepwise therapy, the next step before adding advanced therapies is to optimize anti-inflammatory control by increasing the ICS dose.
  • Seasonal worsening points to allergic triggers, but biologics like omalizumab are reserved for severe, uncontrolled asthma despite maximal inhaled therapy.
  • Before stepping up therapy, clinicians must check adherence, inhaler technique, and remove triggers.
  • Since FEV₁ is normal and there is no bronchodilator reversibility, the main aim is preventing exacerbations - which high-dose ICS can better achieve.

Incorrect Options:

  • Add LAMA (Option B): Tiotropium can be considered in Step 4/5 uncontrolled asthma, but it is generally added after optimizing ICS dose, not before.
  • Add Theophylline (Option C): Due to its narrow therapeutic index, drug interactions, and limited efficacy, theophylline is rarely used in modern asthma management.
  • Add Omalizumab (Option D): Anti-IgE therapy is for severe allergic asthma with raised IgE and positive skin/RAST testing, uncontrolled despite high-dose ICS + LABA. This patient has not yet reached that stage of management.

questions.text: A patient developed Achilles tendonitis and leg swelling after taking a certain antibiotic. This adverse effect is commonly associated with fluoroquinolones. What is the most likely mechanism of action of the drug involved?

choices.text: Inhibition of bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
Inhibition of bacterial protein synthesis at 50S subunit
Inhibition of bacterial folic acid synthesis
Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inhibition of bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV

Explanation:

  • Fluoroquinolones act by inhibiting DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II) and topoisomerase IV, which interferes with DNA replication and leads to bacterial cell death.
  • Fluoroquinolones are associated with tendon toxicity (Achilles tendinopathy/rupture), particularly in older adults, with corticosteroid use, or renal impairment.

Incorrect Options:

  • Inhibition of 50S protein synthesis (Option B): Mechanism of macrolides/ lincomycins/ streptogramins (e.g., erythromycin, clindamycin).
  • Inhibition of folic acid synthesis (Option C): Mechanism of sulfonamides/ trimethoprim.
  • Inhibition of cell wall synthesis (Option D): Mechanism of beta-lactams, glycopeptides.

questions.text: A person was found dead in a swimming pool. On autopsy, his stomach and lungs were filled with water, and there was evidence of mucoid froth at the nose and mouth. What is the most likely mode of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Wet drowning

Explanation:

  • Wet drowning occurs when water enters the airways and lungs during the drowning process, leading to asphyxia. Autopsy findings typically show water in the lungs and stomach, and mucoid froth at the nose and mouth is a classical sign due to mixing of water, air, and surfactant.
  • In wet drowning, inhaled water reaches the alveoli, causing washout of surfactant, alveolar collapse, and hypoxemia. It accounts for the majority of drowning deaths (about 90%). The frothy fluid seen at the mouth and nostrils is often copious and persistent, even after wiping. The stomach may also contain swallowed water.
  • Common causes include accidental submersion, suicidal drowning, and occasionally homicidal drowning.

Specific signs of antemortem drowning

  • Fine white froth at mouth & nostrils — increases on chest compression

  • Overdistended (“ballooned”) lungs — heavy, edematous, exuding watery froth on section

  • Paltauf’s hemorrhages — subpleural bluish-red patches due to rupture of alveolar septa

  • Emphysema aquosum — overinflated, water-filled lungs without putrefactive gases

  • Diatoms in organs (bone marrow, brain) — confirms aspiration of water before death

  • Water in the stomach & small intestine — due to swallowing during the struggle

  • Washerwoman’s hands/feet — wrinkling of skin from immersion (early in both antemortem & postmortem, but more marked in prolonged immersion)

  • Cutis anserina (gooseflesh) — due to contraction of arrector pili muscles

  • Cadaveric spasm: Surest sign of antemortem drowning

Feature

Wet drowning

Dry drowning

Mechanism

Aspiration of water into the lungs

Reflex laryngospasm → asphyxia, minimal/no water in lungs

Froth

Profuse, fine, persistent

Minimal or absent

Lungs

Heavy, water-logged, edematous

Normal or slightly edematous

Stomach contents

Water usually present

Usually absent

Proportion

Most cases (~75–80%)

Fewer cases (~10–20%)

Cause of death

Asphyxia + hemodilution + electrolyte disturbance

Asphyxia due to laryngospasm

Incorrect Options:

Dry drowning (Option A): Occurs due to laryngeal spasm preventing water entry into the lungs; lungs remain dry.

Near drowning (Option C): Refers to survival after submersion for at least 24 hours before death; not applicable here.

Cardiac arrest (Option D): This is the terminal event in many deaths, but it is not the specific mode of death in this case.

questions.text: A patient took a drug for migraine treatment, following which there was numbness, and his hand appeared as below. What is the possible drug that was taken?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dihydroergotamine

Explanation:

  • The patient's numbness and hand discolouration, as shown in the image, suggest treatment with dihydroergotamine for migraine.

Dihydroergotamine

Drug class

Ergot alkaloids

MOA

Partial agonist activity at 5HT1B/1D receptors causes vasoconstriction, reducing migraine-associated inflammation.

Uses

Acute migraine attack

Side effects

  • Peripheral vasoconstriction
    • Manifest as numbness, tingling, and discolouration of the fingers, commonly referred to as Raynaud's phenomenon.
    • Discolouration of fingers - White → Blue→ Red
    • It can lead to gangrene of extremities and organs with end arteries.
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Paradoxical headache and dizziness
  • Flushing
  • Nasal congestion
  • Chest pain
  • Muscle pain

Incorrect Options:

  • Sumatriptan (Option B) is a medication used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks. While it can cause side effects such as tingling or numbness, it is not associated with peripheral vasoconstriction and Raynaud's phenomenon, unlike Dihydroergotamine.
  • Butorphanol (Option C) is an opioid analgesic used for the treatment of pain, including migraines. It is not typically associated with peripheral vasoconstriction and Raynaud's phenomenon.
  • Aspirin (Option D) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used for pain relief. It is not known to cause peripheral vasoconstriction or Raynaud's phenomenon.

questions.text: A 30 year old apparently healthy man who was carrying laxatives and enema apparatus developed abdominal pain at the airport and an x-ray was done which appears as shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
​ Correct Answer: C) Body packer syndrome

Explanation:

  • Body packer's syndrome, also called the surgical mules syndrome is a planned activity to smuggle drugs.
  • The drug to be smuggled is usually wrapped in polythene or condom, and swallowed/planted inside vagina or rectum.
  • The x-ray shows cylindrical objects which may be containers for the drugs.

Incorrect Options:

Bezoar Syndrome (Option A): It is a syndrome in which there is a tightly packed collection of something inside the stomach.Usually, bezoar occurs for a collection of hair inside the stomach, but it can be any indigestible natural/unnatural object.

Pica due to anemia (Option B): It does not present as shown in the case history.

Constipation due to fecalith (Option D): It mostly shows excessive bloating, not shown in the x ray.

questions.text: A patient with hypertension, tachycardia and early renal involvement is prescribed an ARB (telmisartan). What is the most likely mechanism by which the drug helps improve heart rate and blood pressure?

choices.text: By increasing sodium excretion via loop diuretics

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - By decreasing peripheral vascular resistance

Explanation:

  • ARBs (angiotensin II receptor blockers) lower blood pressure primarily by vasodilation - decreasing peripheral vascular resistance (blockade of angiotensin II-mediated vasoconstriction).
  • Lowering BP may secondarily reduce reflex sympathetic activation and improve tachycardia. ARBs do not directly block beta-1 receptors or act as loop diuretics.

Telmisartan

  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Acts as a selective competitive antagonist of AT1 receptors.
  • Use:
    • Hypertension, prevention of cardiovascular events, management of diabetic nephropathy.
  • Special Features:
    • Acts as a peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPAR-γ) agonist, similar to pioglitazone.
    • Stimulation of PPAR-γ leads to improved insulin sensitivity and reduced risk of type 2 diabetes by decreasing insulin resistance

Incorrect Options:

  • Decrease cardiac output directly (Option B): ARBs do not directly reduce cardiac output as a primary mechanism (that’s more characteristic of negative inotropes).
  • Increase sodium excretion via loop diuretics (Option C): Not related - loop diuretics are a separate drug class.
  • Directly blocking beta-1 receptors (Option D): That is the mechanism of beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol), not ARBs.

questions.text: What is the preferred preoperative drug for managing blood pressure in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Phenoxybenzamine

Explanation:

  • Phenoxybenzamine, a long-acting irreversible nonselective α-adrenergic blocker, is the classic recommended preoperative agent for pheochromocytoma to control hypertension and prevent intraoperative catecholamine surges.
  • Alpha blockade should be established before any beta blockade (if needed) to avoid unopposed alpha stimulation.

Treatment of pheochromocytoma

  • Surgical resection:
    • Preoperative: Administer α + β adrenergic blockers.
    • Intraoperative: Perform transabdominal exploration; ensure adequate blood volume and IV fluids to prevent BP drop.
  • Metastatic disease: 1st line: Nuclear medicine therapy (I-131-MIBG) in 100-300 mCi doses over 3-6 cycles for scintigraphically documented metastasis.
  • Prolonged Follow-up: It is indicated because Functioning tumors at other sites may be manifested many years after the initial Operation.
  • Screening: Examine relatives, as asymptomatic tumors may be present.
  • Malignancy: True indicators of malignancy are metastasis or local invasiveness, that precludes complete resection or both, more common in extra-adrenal sites and SHDB gene mutations.

Incorrect Options:

  • Propranolol (Option A): A nonselective beta-blocker - must only be given after adequate alpha blockade.
  • Prazosin (Option C): Selective α1 blocker used in some settings; phenoxybenzamine remains the classic preop drug.
  • Labetalol (Option D): Has combined alpha and beta blockade but is not preferred as sole initial preop blockade.

questions.text: A woman taking cetirizine for allergic rhinitis complains of excessive sleepiness. Which of the following is the best alternative with minimal sedative effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fexofenadine

Explanation:

  • Fexofenadine is a second-generation, non-sedating antihistamine with minimal central nervous system penetration and minimal sedative effects - a good substitute for a sedating agent like cetirizine in sensitive individuals.

Drugs that act by blocking Histamine H1 receptors:

Generation

Drug

Side Effects

Generalised Uses

1st Generation

Diphenhydramine

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision

Allergy symptoms, Insomnia, Motion sickness

Chlorpheniramine

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth

Allergy symptoms

Hydroxyzine

Anxiety, Allergy symptoms, Pruritus

2nd Generation

Loratadine

Minimal sedation, dry mouth

Allergy symptoms, Urticaria

Cetirizine

Allergy symptoms, Itchiness, Urticaria

Fexofenadine

Non-sedating, minimal side effects

Allergy symptoms, Chronic idiopathic urticaria

Incorrect Options:

  • Hydroxyzine (Option A), Diphenhydramine (Option B), Promethazine (Option D): All first-generation H1 antagonists with significant sedative properties.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tolcapone

Explanation:

  • Tolcapone acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme.

Tolcapone

MOA

It inhibits the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme, which is responsible for the breakdown of catecholamines, prolonging the action of catechols in the CNS and peripheral tissue.

Uses

Adjunct therapy in Parkinson’s disease.

Side effects

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • On/Off phenomenon
    • Neurological Symptoms:
      • Dyskinesia (due to increased levodopa bioavailability)
      • Dizziness
      • Headache
      • Sleep disturbances (e.g., insomnia)
    • Psychiatric Symptoms:
      • Hallucinations
      • Confusion
      • Increased impulsive behaviours

Incorrect Options:

  • Amantadine (Option A) is an antiviral and antiparkinsonian medication that primarily acts by increasing the release of dopamine and inhibiting its reuptake. It does not inhibit the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme.
  • Rotigotine (Option B) is a dopamine agonist used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and restless legs syndrome. It stimulates dopamine receptors directly and does not inhibit the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme.
  • Selegiline (Option D) is a selective monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibitor, which increases dopamine levels by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine by the MAO-B enzyme. It does not directly inhibit the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme.

questions.text: A patient presents with blackish discoloration of the nasal cavity and posterior buccal mucosa. He has a history of high-dose steroid use. What is the most appropriate drug for treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Amphotericin B

Explanation:

  • The presentation suggests mucormycosis (black necrotic tissue of nasal/oral mucosa in an immunosuppressed patient, e.g., on high-dose steroids).
  • The first-line antifungal for invasive mucormycosis is lipid formulation amphotericin B (systemic).
  • Early surgical debridement plus amphotericin B is standard.

Amphotericin B

  • Derived from Streptomyces nodosus
  • Given I.V
  • Most effective drug
  • Fungicidal drug
  • Use- Broad spectrum drug
  • DOC
    • Serious invasive fungal infection
      • Cryptococcal meningitis, Mucormycosis, Coccidial meningitis.
      • IVinduction
      • If improved oral azoles as maintenance
    • Kala-azar: protozoal infection
      • Leishmania donovani
  • Should not be given at home
  • In hospitalized patients, a drip of amphotericin B + 5% dextrose is given under supervision.
    • It is insoluble in normal saline and Ringer's lactate.

Incorrect Options:

  • Fluconazole (Option A) and Itraconazole (Option C): Not effective against mucorales.
  • Griseofulvin (Option D): Used for superficial dermatophyte infections only.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department with signs suggest opioid poisoning. What is the antidote of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Naloxone

Explanation:

  • Naloxone is the opioid antagonist that rapidly reverses opioid-induced respiratory depression and miosis — it is the antidote of choice in suspected opioid overdose.

Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning

Cause

Clinical, accidental, or suicidal overdose.

Symptoms
  • Unconsiousness/coma
  • Miosis: Pin point pupil
  • Respiratory depression
  • Dry secretion in the eye/mouth
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Flaccid muscles
  • Convulsions (in children)

Management

Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote)

                            ↓

Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):

  • Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol
  • Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine

                            ↓

Abstinence (Prevent relapse):

  • DOC: Oral Naltrexone

Incorrect Options:

  • Flumazenil (Option A): Antagonizes benzodiazepines, not opioids.
  • Atropine (Option B): Anticholinergic agent - not the antidote for opioids.
  • Physostigmine (Option D): For anticholinergic overdose; not for opioid toxicity.

questions.text: What is Zileuton's mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 5-Lipooxygenase inhibitor

Explanation:

  • Zileuton is a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor, which is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes.
  • It is primarily used to maintain asthma and is particularly effective in reducing bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation in conditions like asthma.


Incorrect Options:

  • Cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibitors (Option A), such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), work by inhibiting the activity of the COX enzymes involved in the production of prostaglandins and thromboxanes. Zileuton does not inhibit cyclooxygenase.
  • 5-phosphodiesterase inhibitors (Option C) inhibit the enzyme that breaks down cyclic nucleotides like cAMP and cGMP. Drugs like sildenafil are used for erectile dysfunction and pulmonary arterial hypertension. Zileuton does not inhibit 5-phosphodiesterase.
  • Prevention of mast cell degranulation (Option D) is seen with mast cell stabilisers, like cromolyn sodium. Mast cell degranulation refers to the release of inflammatory mediators, such as histamine and cytokines, from mast cells. Zileuton does not directly prevent mast cell degranulation.

questions.text: A patient with hypertension is taking anti-hypertensive drugs but BP is not controlled even after adding diuretics in treatment. Patoent’s serum electrolyte shows hypokalemia. What is the next step in treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Spironolactone

Explanation:

  • A patient with hypertension not controlled despite multiple drugs including diuretics with hypokalemia, suggests a case of secondary cause of hypertension, most likely primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn’s syndrome).

Primary hyperaldosteronism → excess aldosterone from adrenal adenoma or hyperplasia.

Aldosterone causes:

  • ↑ Na⁺ reabsorption → ↑ blood volume → hypertension.
  • ↑ K⁺ excretion → hypokalemia.

BP stays high even with usual drugs because the underlying cause (aldosterone excess) is untreated.

Spironolactone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist (potassium-sparing diuretic).

Directly blocks aldosterone’s action in the distal nephron:

  • ↓ Na⁺ reabsorption
  • ↓ K⁺ excretion (helps correct hypokalemia)
  • ↓ BP by reducing volume overload

It’s both diagnostic and therapeutic in suspected primary hyperaldosteronism.

Incorrect Options:

  • KCl (Option A): Will temporarily correct hypokalemia but won’t fix the underlying aldosterone excess or the hypertension.
  • Torasemide (Option C): Loop diuretic → will worsen hypokalemia and not target aldosterone-driven hypertension.
  • Hydrochlorothiazide (Option D): Thiazide diuretic → also increases potassium loss; will worsen hypokalemia.

questions.text: A patient presents with lung injury and tympanic membrane rupture following a blast exposure. These injuries are characteristic of which level of blast wave effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Level I

Explanation:

  • Primary (Level I) blast injuries are caused directly by the impact of the overpressure wave from the blast. Air-filled organs are particularly vulnerable because of the difference in tissue density.
  • The lungs (blast lung injury) and tympanic membranes (perforation) are the most commonly affected due to their air-containing structure.
  • Pathophysiology involves rapid compression and decompression, causing tissue disruption, hemorrhage, and edema.
  • Clinical manifestations may include hemoptysis, dyspnea, hypoxia (from pulmonary barotrauma), and hearing loss.
  • These injuries occur without physical contact with flying debris- the pressure wave alone is responsible.
  • High-yield point: Tympanic membrane rupture is considered a sensitive marker of exposure to a significant blast overpressure, but absence of rupture does not rule out lung injury.

Classification of Blast Injuries:

Type

Mechanism

Features

Primary Injury

It results from blast waves and is often internal with no external signs.
  • Ears: Tympanic membrane rupture or inner ear disruption.
  • Lungs: Alveolar-capillary membrane haemorrhage (blast lung), most common cause cause of death in survivors.
  • GIT: Injuries to gas-filled organs are more common in underwater blasts.

Secondary Injury

It is resulting from shrapnel, debris & flying objects (propelled by explosion).
  • Penetrating trauma.
  • The characteristic Marshall triad, which includes bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations, is evident.
  • Commonly cause severe thoracic injuries, including lacerations of the heart and great vessels.

Tertiary Injury

Victims are thrown against solid objects by blast winds.
  • Blunt/ Penetrating trauma.
  • Includes bone fractures and coup-contrecoup injuries.

Quaternary Injury

Encompass all other injuries not classified above
  • Flash burns from extreme heat.
  • Crush injuries and falls due to explosions.
  • Respiratory injuries from toxic dust, gases, or radiation exposure.
  • Psychiatric issues, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), may affect individuals even if they are physically unharmed.

Incorrect Options:

  • Level II (Option B): Caused by flying debris from the blast, leading to penetrating or blunt trauma, not by direct pressure wave effects.
  • Level III (Option C): Result from the victim being thrown by the blast wind, causing blunt injuries or fractures from impact, not barotrauma.
  • Level IV (Option D): Due to burns, inhalational injuries, or exposure to chemicals from the blast, not lung or ear barotrauma.

questions.text: A patient presents with a fish bone stuck in the pyriform sinus. During the removal procedure, there is accidental nerve injury. Which nerve is most likely to be damaged?

choices.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve pierces the thyrohyoid membrane along with the superior laryngeal artery to supply sensory innervation to the mucosa of the larynx above the vocal cords, the pharynx, and the pyriform sinus.
  • In cases of foreign body removal from the pyriform sinus, this nerve lies in close proximity and is at high risk of injury.
  • Damage results in loss of sensation in the supraglottic larynx and pyriform sinus, predisposing to aspiration because the protective cough reflex is lost.
  • This nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve and has no motor component - purely sensory in this region.

Incorrect Options:

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (Option A): Supplies motor innervation to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except cricothyroid and sensory innervation below the vocal cords. It is not exposed during pyriform sinus procedures.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option B): Provides sensation to the oropharynx, posterior one-third of the tongue, and tonsillar region, not the pyriform sinus.
  • External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (Option D): Supplies motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle and is located more superficially, away from the pyriform sinus mucosa, making injury unlikely during this procedure.

questions.text: What surgery is being performed in the image shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Total maxillectomy

Explanation:

  • The Weber–Ferguson incision is a classical surgical approach for accessing the maxilla and paranasal sinuses, providing wide exposure.
  • The image shows an exposed maxillary cavity with removal of anterior and medial walls, which is characteristic of a total maxillectomy.
  • Total maxillectomy involves removal of the entire maxilla, including anterior, medial, posterior, and inferior walls, usually performed for malignant tumors of the maxilla or advanced sinonasal malignancies.
  • In the given scenario, the surgical field and the incision markings confirm the diagnosis of total maxillectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Total ethmoidectomy (Option A): Complete removal of the ethmoid air cells, done for extensive ethmoid sinus disease, not for lesions requiring maxillary bone removal.

Partial ethmoidectomy (Option B): Involves selective removal of diseased ethmoid cells while preserving healthy mucosa, unrelated to the maxillary walls.

Partial maxillectomy (Option D): Involves removal of only part of the maxilla (e.g., medial wall in medial maxillectomy) while sparing other bony walls; in the image, multiple walls are removed indicating a total, not partial, procedure.

questions.text: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is most strongly associated with which of the following head and neck cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Oropharyngeal carcinoma

Explanation:

  • HPV, especially HPV-16, is strongly linked to oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, involving sites such as the tonsils and base of tongue.
  • These cancers often occur in younger, non-smoking individuals, have a better prognosis, and are driven by the E6 and E7 viral oncoproteins that inactivate p53 and Rb tumor suppressor pathways.
  • In the clinical context, HPV testing is important for prognosis and treatment planning, as HPV-positive tumors respond better to chemoradiotherapy.
  • HPV
    • HPV 6 and 11 cause juvenile respiratory papillomatosis which rarely undergoes malignant change
    • Sexual behaviors and HPV infection are strongly associated with oropharyngeal cancers, but there is limited epidemiological evidence connecting these factors with laryngeal cancers.
    • Unlike oropharyngeal cancer, current studies do not show an improved prognosis for HPV-positive laryngeal tumors.

Incorrect Options:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option A): Strongly associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection, not HPV.
  • Hypopharyngeal carcinoma (Option B): More commonly linked to tobacco and alcohol abuse rather than HPV infection.
  • Laryngeal carcinoma (Option C): Usually related to smoking and alcohol; HPV may play a minor role but not the strongest association.

questions.text: A professional singer presents with difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice following thyroid surgery. There is no hoarseness, but high-pitched voice production is impaired. Which nerve is most likely injured?

choices.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN)
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN)

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN)

Explanation:

  • The EBSLN innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords to produce high-pitched sounds.
  • Injury during thyroid surgery can cause inability to raise pitch without causing hoarseness, since vocal cord mobility is preserved.
  • Professional voice users (singers, actors) often notice this subtle change more than regular speakers.

Unilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Cricothyroid muscle - decreased ability to tense the vocal cord.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cord on the affected side.
  • Vocal Cord Position: The affected vocal cord appears shortened and wavy; may exhibit flapping due to loss of tension.
  • Other Features:
    • Askew position of the glottis with the anterior commissure rotated towards the healthy side.
    • Voice changes such as weakness and inability to raise pitch, affecting singing ability.
  • Treatment: Primarily voice therapy to improve vocal function and manage symptoms.

Bilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Both cricothyroid muscles - bilateral loss of vocal cord tension.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cords bilaterally.
  • Vocal Cord Position: Both vocal cords may be shortened and lack tension, potentially leading to difficulties with voice production.
  • Other Features:
    • Inhalation of food and secretions resulting in coughing and choking.
    • The voice is weak and husky.
  • Treatment:
    • Tracheostomy with a cuffed tube and esophageal feeding tube, if aspiration is severe.
    • Epiglottopexy (reversible) - close laryngeal inlet - to protect the lungs from aspiration.
    • Voice pitch improvement through surgical approximation of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages.

Joll’s Triangle (Sternothyroid-laryngeal triangle)

An anatomical landmark used for identifying and preserving the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN).

  • Superior border by the upper attachment of the strap muscles.
  • Medial border by the midline of the neck.
  • Lateral border by the upper pole of the thyroid gland and the superior thyroid vessels.
  • Floor of the Triangle: The EBSLN is located in the floor of the triangle, which is delineated by the cricothyroid muscle.

Incorrect Options:

  • Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN) (Option B): Provides sensory supply to the mucosa above the vocal cords; injury leads to loss of laryngeal sensation, not pitch alteration.
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) (Option C): Supplies all intrinsic laryngeal muscles (except cricothyroid); injury causes hoarseness due to vocal cord palsy, not isolated pitch change.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option D): Provides sensation to the oropharynx and taste to the posterior third of the tongue; unrelated to pitch control.

questions.text: The image below shows a lateral view of the face with a highlighted region in front of the ear. Which type of abscess is most likely indicated in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Luc's abscess

Explanation:

  • Luc’s abscess is a subperiosteal abscess in the external auditory canal region due to spread of pus from the mastoid antrum through erosion of the outer cortex without mastoid tip involvement.
  • It presents as swelling in the preauricular region or posterior wall of the external auditory canal (as shown in the image).
  • More common in children because their mastoid bone is softer and thinner.
  • Key point: It is one of the less common mastoid-related abscesses, distinct from the more frequent post-auricular abscess.

Incorrect Options:

Citelli’s abscess (Option A): Occurs when pus tracks into the posterior belly of the digastric muscle, presenting as a swelling in the upper neck behind the angle of the mandible.

Bezold’s abscess (Option C): Caused by pus from mastoiditis eroding the mastoid tip and tracking deep to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, producing swelling in the upper neck.

Zygomatic abscess (Option D): Results from infection spreading to zygomatic root cells, presenting as swelling over the temporal region above and in front of the ear.

questions.text: A patient presents with enophthalmos and periorbital ecchymosis after being hit by a ball. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Orbital blowout fracture

Explanation:

  • In this patient, blunt trauma caused orbital floor damage with herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary sinus, explaining the enophthalmos. The periorbital ecchymosis and lack of facial flattening point toward an isolated orbital blowout fracture rather than zygomatic or nasal bone injury.

Orbital floor fracture (also known as blow-out fracture):

  • A blow-out fracture usually occurs due to a sudden rise in orbital pressure from an impacting object, like a fist or tennis ball, causing the eyeball to be displaced and transmit, rather than absorb, the impact.

Classification:

  • Pure blow-out fractures are isolated to the orbital walls (floor or medial wall) without involving the orbital rim.
  • Impure blow-out fractures involve the orbital walls, the orbital rim, and surrounding facial bones.

Clinical features:

  • Periorbital oedema and blood extravasation in and around the orbit (such as subconjunctival ecchymosis)
  • Emphysema (subcutaneous) of the eyelids
  • Paraesthesia and anaesthesia in the distribution of infraorbital nerve (lower lid, cheek, side of nose, upper lip, and upper teeth).
  • Ipsilateral epistaxis (bleeding from maxillary sinus)
  • Proptosis (orbital oedema and haemorrhage).
  • Enophthalmos and mechanical ptosis
  • Diplopia (oedema, haemorrhage, entrapment of muscle (inferior rectus/inferior oblique) at the fracture site.
  • Hess chart testing (map eye movements for assessment and monitoring).

Orbital imaging:

  • X-rays: A nose-chin (Water's) view showing 'hanging drop' opacity of the superior maxillary antrum from orbital contents herniating through the floor.

Plain X-ray orbit (AP view) showing herniated orbital contents (arrow) with blow-out fracture of the orbital floor

  • Computerised tomography (CT) scanning and magnetic resonance imaging(MRI): Evaluate the extent of the fracture and herniation of contents into maxillary antrum (hanging drop or tear drop sign).

 

CT scan of coronal section of orbit showing fracture floor with herniation of orbital contents

 

Management:

  • Antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Ice packs and nasal decongestants
  • Surgery (dislodge the muscle and do microplating)
    • Indications for surgery:
      • No improvement in diplopia or enophthalmos even after 10 days (indicates muscle entrapment).
      • Enopthalmos is > 2mm
      • Half of the floor is fractured

Incorrect Options:

  • Zygomatic fracture (Option B): Usually causes flattening of the cheek, trismus from masseter involvement, and infraorbital nerve paresthesia rather than isolated enophthalmos.
  • Nasal bone fracture (Option C): Presents with nasal deformity, tenderness, and epistaxis, not enophthalmos.
  • Le Fort I fracture (Option D): Involves a horizontal maxillary fracture above the teeth, causing mobility of the upper jaw; not typically associated with isolated orbital findings.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of fall and is found to have bleeding from the ear on examination. What is the investigation of choice ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CT Temporal bone

Explanation:
Post-traumatic ear bleeding is highly suggestive of a temporal bone fracture, often with involvement of the middle or inner ear. High-resolution CT of the temporal bone is the gold standard for detecting fracture lines, ossicular injury, and associated complications.

  • Temporal bone fractures may be longitudinal, transverse, or mixed, each with distinct clinical features and risks to hearing and balance.
  • Associated findings can include CSF otorrhea, facial nerve palsy, hearing loss, and vertigo.
  • High-resolution CT (HRCT) provides detailed imaging of the petrous bone, ossicles, mastoid air cells, and otic capsule.
  • Early diagnosis helps guide surgical intervention, prevent infectious complications, and preserve hearing and nerve function.
  • MRI is reserved for suspected soft-tissue or brain injuries, not for acute bony detail.

Incorrect Options:

  • CBC (Option A): Useful for general trauma evaluation but does not help in diagnosing bone fractures.
  • MRI Brain (Option B): Ideal for soft tissue and intracranial injuries but lacks the bony resolution required for temporal bone assessment.
  • X-ray Skull (Option D): Poor sensitivity for temporal bone fractures and unable to adequately visualize complex bony anatomy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man complains of gradual hearing loss over several years. He reports difficulty hearing conversations, especially in noisy environments, and has trouble perceiving high-pitched sounds. There are no episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, or ear fullness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Presbycusis

Explanation:
This patient’s progressive high-frequency hearing loss with difficulty understanding speech in noisy settings is classic for presbycusis. It is a symmetric, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss due to age-related degeneration of cochlear hair cells, particularly in the basal turn of the cochlea.

  • Definition: Gradual, bilateral, symmetric, sensorineural hearing loss of aging.
  • Mechanism: Degeneration of hair cells & supporting structures starting at cochlear base → affects high frequencies first.
  • Key Features:
    • High-frequency loss precedes low-frequency loss.
    • Speech discrimination difficulty, especially in noisy environments.
    • No vertigo or tinnitus as primary complaint.
  • Audiogram Finding: Down-sloping pattern toward high frequencies.
  • Management: Hearing aids, auditory rehabilitation; prevention focuses on avoiding noise exposure.
  • Complications if untreated: Social withdrawal, depression, cognitive decline.

Incorrect Options:

  • Meniere’s disease (Option A): Characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating low-frequency hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness - not isolated high-frequency loss.
  • Otosclerosis (Option B): Conductive hearing loss due to stapes footplate fixation; often starts in young adulthood and improves in noisy environments (Paracusis Willisii).
  • Acoustic neuroma (Option D): Unilateral progressive sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus ± imbalance; MRI is diagnostic, not typically symmetric high-frequency loss.

questions.text: A diabetic male presents with facial pain and blackish discoloration in the nose. The CT image shows bone erosion and sinus involvement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis

Explanation:

  • This patient’s uncontrolled diabetes and presentation with black necrotic tissue in the nasal cavity along with CT evidence of bone destruction strongly suggest mucormycosis. This aggressive fungal infection, usually caused by Rhizopus species, invades blood vessels, causing tissue necrosis and rapid spread to orbit and brain.

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis

  • Fulminant, angioinvasive fungal infection affecting immunocompromised patients, especially diabetics in ketoacidosis.
  • Causative organisms: Rhizopus, Mucor, Lichtheimia species.
  • Mechanism: Fungal spores → nasal mucosa → blood vessel invasion → thrombosis & tissue necrosis → spread to orbit/brain.
  • Key Features:
    • Facial pain, swelling, nasal congestion.
    • Black eschar on nasal mucosa or palate.
    • Ophthalmoplegia, vision loss if orbital spread occurs.
    • Altered sensorium in advanced cases.
  • Imaging clue: CT/MRI - sinus opacification, bone destruction, orbital involvement
  • Management: Urgent surgical debridement + high-dose IV liposomal amphotericin B + strict glycemic control.
  • Prognosis: High mortality; early diagnosis improves outcomes.

 

Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus

  

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a.  

b. 

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

Incorrect Options:

  • Acute bacterial sinusitis (Option A): Usually presents with purulent nasal discharge, facial pressure, and fever; lacks black necrotic tissue and bone erosion on imaging.
  • Allergic fungal sinusitis (Option B): Chronic, non-invasive fungal reaction in immunocompetent patients; shows sinus expansion but not tissue necrosis or bone destruction.
  • Nasal polyposis (Option C): Benign, pale, edematous mucosal growths causing nasal obstruction; no pain, necrosis, or invasive bone destruction.

questions.text: A tympanometry graph is shown below. An arrow indicates a shallow peak at pressure = 0 daPa. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the tympanometry result shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Type As

Explanation:
The tympanogram shows a normal middle ear pressure (peak at 0 daPa) but reduced compliance (shallow peak). This pattern is diagnostic of Type As tympanogram, which indicates stiffening of the middle ear system. Common causes:

  • Otosclerosis (stapes fixation)
  • Tympanosclerosis (post-infection scarring)
  • Thickened tympanic membrane

Impedance audiometry: Impedance audiometry comprises of acoustic reflex and tympanometry.

A. Tympanometry:

  • Measures the compliance (stiffness) of the tympano-ossicular system by detecting the reflected sound energy.
  • Can also test Eustachian tube function by pressure changes and swallowing.
  • Different tympanogram types indicate middle ear pathologies:

Tympanogram Type

Characteristics

Indication

Type A

Normal peak

Normal middle ear function

Type As

Shallow peak

Ossicular fixation (e.g., otosclerosis)

Type Ad

Deep peak

Ossicular discontinuity or thin tympanic membrane

Type B

Flat, no peak

Middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane

Type C

Peak at negative pressure

Eustachian tube dysfunction, middle ear negative pressure

B. Acoustic Reflex (Stapedial Reflex):

  • Measures the stapedial muscle contraction in response to loud sounds (70-100 dB above threshold).
  • Useful for:
    • Assessing hearing in infants and young children.
    • Detecting malingering.
    • Diagnosing cochlear and CN VIII pathologies.
    • Assessing facial nerve function and brainstem lesions.

Incorrect Options:

Type A (Option A): Normal peak height and position; indicates normal middle ear function - does not match the shallow peak here.

Type B (Option B): Flat tracing with no peak; suggests middle ear effusion or perforation - not seen in this case.

Type Ad (Option D): Peak at 0 daPa but with hypercompliance (very tall peak), seen in ossicular discontinuity or thin TM - opposite finding here.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Meniere's Disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ear Pain

Explanation:

  • Meniere’s disease is an inner ear disorder characterized by episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and aural fullness due to endolymphatic hydrops. However, ear pain is not a typical feature of Meniere’s disease unless secondary infections or complications occur.

Meniere’s Disease

Feature

Description

Cause

Excess endolymph accumulation (endolymphatic hydrops)

Triad of Symptoms

1. Vertigo (episodic, lasts minutes to hours)

2. Tinnitus (low-frequency, roaring type)

3. Hearing loss (sensorineural, fluctuating, progressive)

Other Symptoms

Aural fullness (blocked ear sensation)

Not Typically Seen

Ear pain, except in secondary infections

Diagnosis

Clinical + Audiometry (low-frequency SNHL)

Treatment

Dietary modifications (low sodium), diuretics, vestibular suppressants, intratympanic steroids, and surgery in refractory cases

Incorrect Options:

  • Tinnitus (Option A): is incorrect because tinnitus (low-pitched, roaring) is a hallmark of Meniere’s disease.
  • Vertigo (Option B): is incorrect because Meniere’s disease presents with episodic vertigo, lasting minutes to hours.
  • Fullness of ear (Option C): is incorrect because aural fullness or pressure sensation in the affected ear is a classic symptom.

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever, malaise, and diarrhea. There is a history of exposure to livestock. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Coxiella burnetii

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a farmer with acute febrile illness after exposure to livestock suggests the diagnosis of Q fever, a zoonotic infection caused by Coxiella burnetii.
  • Source → Infected livestock (cattle, sheep, goats) — bacteria found in birth products, urine, faeces, and milk.
  • Transmission → Inhalation of aerosolized particles (often from contaminated hay, barn dust, or animal waste).
  • Symptoms → Fever, malaise, myalgia, headache; may include pneumonia or hepatitis.
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhoea can occur, especially in acute infection.
  • No rash (unlike many other rickettsial infections).

Rickettsia rickettsii (Option A): Rocky Mountain spotted fever; requires tick bite; classic triad is fever, rash and history of tick exposure.

Rickettsia typhi (Option B): Murine (endemic) typhus; transmitted by fleas from rodents, not livestock.

Orientia tsutsugamushi (Option D): Scrub typhus; transmitted by chigger mites; seen in rural/forest scrub areas, not directly from livestock.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever after returning from a forest trip. On examination, a black eschar is noted on the abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and its drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Doxycycline

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever and a black eschar (site of the bite) after a forest trip is suggestive of mild to moderate Scrub Typhus in which Doxycycline is given.

 

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi (bacteria)

Transmission

Chiggers (larval mites)

Vector

Trombiculid mite (Leptotrombidium)

Geographical distribution

Endemic in the “tsutsugamushi triangle” (parts of Asia, Australia, Pacific Islands).

Clinical manifestations

Fever, headache, muscle pain, eschar (dark, scab-like lesion at the site of bite), and lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis

Serological tests (ELISA, immunofluorescence) and molecular methods (PCR).

Treatment

Antibiotics (Doxycycline, Azithromycin)

Prevention

Avoid mite-infested areas, wearing protective clothing, and using insect repellants.

Complications

Organ failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), neurological complications.

Penicillin (Option A): Not effective against rickettsial organisms.

Ceftriaxone (Option C): Used for bacterial meningitis, typhoid, gonorrhea, not scrub typhus.

Artesunate (Option D): Antimalarial; used for severe Plasmodium falciparum malaria.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with whitish plaques in the oral cavity. A KOH mount confirms the presence of budding yeast with pseudohyphae. Which of the following is the most appropriate culture medium for isolation of this organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA)

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis is Oral candidiasis/ Moniliasis, indicated by the presence of white patches in the oral cavity and the patient's risk factor such as diabetes. It is caused by Candida albicans, which is cultured on SDA agar.

 

Investigations for Candida albicans :

  • KOH: This shows budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae

  • Fungal culture: It shows a creamy white colony.
  • Germ Tube Test is a screening test that is used to differentiate Candida Albicans from other yeast. When Candida is grown in human or sheep serum at 37°C for 3 hours, they form a germ tube, which can be detected with a wet KOH films as filamentous outgrowth extending from yeast cells.

Germ Tube Test

Culture

KOH Mount

 

Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Presence of white patches that can be scraped off leaving behind a red, inflamed base

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increase susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Leads to an increase in fungal colonisation.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment
  • Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.
  • C. krusei- Resistant to azoles

 

Chocolate agar (Option A): Enriched medium for fastidious bacteria (Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria), not fungi.

Thayer-Martin medium (Option C): Selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae & N. meningitidis; contains antibiotics to suppress other microbes.

Loeffler’s serum slope (Option D):Enrichment medium for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: What is the vector responsible for transmitting the Zika virus among the options listed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aedes albopictus

Explanation:

  • Aedes albopictus, also known as the Asian tiger mosquito, is one of the primary vectors responsible for transmitting the Zika virus. This mosquito species, along with Aedes aegypti, plays a major role in the spread of Zika, as well as other viral infections like dengue and chikungunya.

Zika virus:

  • Zika virus (ZIKV) is an arbovirus from the Flaviviridae family, characterized by its single-stranded RNA.

Transmission:

  • ZIKV is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquito.
  • Other transmission modes include mother-to-child (especially in the first trimester), and rarely through sexual contact, blood transfusion, and organ transplantation.

The life cycle of Zika virus

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Incubation: A few days to 1 week; >80% of infections are asymptomatic.
  • Zika Fever: Symptoms include mild fever, rash, and conjunctivitis.
  • Congenital Zika Syndrome (CZS): Characterized by microcephaly and neurological issues.
  • Neurological Complications: Rarely includes Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT): RT-PCR is the preferred method, detecting ZIKV RNA in blood and urine up to 7 days after symptom onset.
  • IgM Antibody Detection: Appears after 1 week of symptoms and can remain positive for several months; may cross-react with dengue antibodies.
  • Enzyme Immunoassays (EIAs) and Immunofluorescence Assays (IFA): Used if symptoms last ≥ 7 days, utilizing viral lysate or recombinant proteins.

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man develops profuse vomiting and diarrhea within 3 hours of consuming pre-packaged salad and milk at a picnic. There is no fever. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Staphylococcus aureus

Explanation:

  • The very short incubation period (1–6 hours) after food ingestion, combined with the absence of fever and the involvement of dairy/salad-type foods, points strongly to preformed, heat-stable enterotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • S. aureus produces enterotoxins (types A, B, C, D, E) that are resistant to heat and gastric enzymes, leading to sudden-onset nausea, vomiting, and sometimes diarrhea.
  • Because illness is due to ingestion of toxin (not bacterial multiplication in the body), symptoms appear rapidly and resolve within 24–48 hours.

Clostridium perfringens (Option A): Causes a toxin-mediated diarrheal illness but incubation is longer (usually 8–16 h) and linked to reheated meat/gravies.

Salmonella enterica (Option B): Typically causes invasive gastroenteritis with longer incubation (6–72 h) and fever.

Bacillus cereus (Option D): Has two syndromes - emetic form (short incubation 1–5 h, often linked to chinese food) and diarrheal form (longer).

questions.text: A woman presents with sudden-onset high-grade fever, hypotension, diffuse rash, and a history of using a tampon for an extended period. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Toxic Shock Syndrome

Explanation:

  • This clinical triad (fever, hypotension/shock, diffuse erythrodermic rash with history of tampon use) is most consistent with Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) caused by toxin-producing Staphylococcus aureus (TSST-1) or sometimes group A Streptococcus.
  • TSST-1 is a superantigen that triggers massive, non-specific T-cell activation and cytokine release → shock and rash; desquamation of palms/soles later is typical.

Major Criteria (All Required)

  • Acute fever; temperature >38.8° C (101.8° F)
  • Hypotension (orthostatic, shock; blood pressure below age-appropriate norms)
  • Rash (erythroderma with convalescent desquamation)

Minor Criteria (Any 3 or more)

  • Mucous membrane inflammation (vaginal, oropharyngeal or conjunctival hyperemia, strawberry tongue)
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Liver abnormalities (bilirubin or transaminase greater than twice the upper limit of normal)
  • Renal abnormalities (blood urea nitrogen or creatinine greater than twice the upper limit of normal, or greater than 5 white blood cells per high-power field)
  • Muscle abnormalities (myalgia or creatinine phosphokinase greater than twice the upper limit of normal)
  • CNS abnormalities (alteration in consciousness without focal neurologic signs)
  • Thrombocytopenia

Treatment:

  • Supportive - IVFluids +/- Ionotropes
  • One course of Anti-staphylococcal antibiotics

Septic shock (Option A): May cause hypotension and high fever, but TSS has a characteristic diffuse rash and association with tampon/exogenous foreign body and superantigen mechanism.

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (Option C): Presents with pelvic pain, cervical motion tenderness; systemic hypotension and diffuse rash are not characteristic.

Streptococcal pharyngitis (Option D): Localized sore throat ± fever; not the shock/rash pattern described.

questions.text: Receptor used for the entry of HIV virus into the host cell is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CCR5

Explanation:

  • CCR5 (C-C chemokine receptor type 5) is one of the primary receptors used by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) to enter host cells. Specifically, CCR5 is found on the surface of CD4+ T cells and other immune cells, and HIV binds to it along with CD4 (another receptor) in order to gain entry into the host cell.

Modes of Transmission of HIV

  • Sexual Transmission:
    • Most common (75% of cases).
    • Heterosexual Route: Male to female via vaginal intercourse is typical; risk per encounter is low (0.1–1%). Higher risk with anal intercourse.
  • Blood Transfusion: Least common (5% of cases) but has a high transmission risk (90–95%).
  • Percutaneous/Mucosal Transmission: Includes needle stick injuries and sharing razors; less effective compared to sexual transmission.
  • Perinatal Transmission: 20–40% risk of mother-to-fetus transmission without intervention; highest risk during delivery.
  • Casual Contact: No evidence of transmission through casual contact, kissing, or insect bites.
  • Viral Load: Highest in blood, genital secretions, and cerebrospinal fluid; minimal in saliva and other body fluids.
  • Saliva: Contains substances that may inhibit HIV transmission.

Pathogenesis:

  • Receptor Attachment
    • Main Receptor:
      • HIV binds its gp120 to the CD4 receptor on host cells, primarily expressed on helper T cells and other cells like monocytes and macrophages.
    • Co-Receptors: Fusion requires a second receptor:
      • CXCR4: Found on T lymphocytes.
      • CCR5: Present on macrophage lineage cells. (Option B)
    • DC-SIGN:
      • A dendritic cell-specific receptor that binds HIV-1 but does not mediate entry; facilitates transport to lymphoid organs.
    • CCR5 Delta 32 Mutation:
      • Mutation can block HIV entry:
        1. Homozygous individuals are resistant to HIV (1% of Northern Europeans).
        2. Heterozygous individuals may have delayed progression to AIDS (10–15% of Europeans).
  • Replication

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. These are not used as a receptor for the entry of HIV into the host cells.

questions.text: What is the most likely causative agent for a Tzanck smear showing multinucleated cells?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Herpes simplex virus

Explanation:

  • A positive Tzanck smear demonstrates multinucleated giant epithelial cells and is classically associated with herpetic infections — most commonly Herpes simplex virus (HSV).
  • The presence of multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck supports a herpesvirus family etiology (HSV or VZV), but HSV is the most frequent cause for localized herpetic lesions.

Varicella-zoster virus (Option A): Also a herpesvirus and can produce multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck; however, when asked “most likely” in a general context, HSV is the usual single best answer for a positive Tzanck smear.

Human papillomavirus (Option C): Causes koilocytosis — not multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck.

Coxsackievirus A16 (Option D): Causes HFMD; does not give a positive Tzanck smear.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with lower abdominal pain and diarrhoea. The stool examination finding is shown below. Which of the following is most likely the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Entamoeba histolytica

Explanation:

  • The given image is of E. histolytica trophozoites.
  • Entamoeba histolytica is the causative organism of amoebic dysentery, which can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and sometimes bloody stools. In the case of a child presenting with lower abdominal pain and diarrhea, Entamoeba histolytica should be strongly considered, especially when stool examination reveals characteristic trophozoites or cysts under the microscope. These trophozoites often have a distinctive central nucleus and can cause tissue destruction in the colon, leading to ulcerations and diarrhea.

Entamoeba histolytica

Trophozoite

Cyst
  • Pointed pseudopodia
  • Single nucleus
  • Central karyosome
  • Cartwheel nucleus
  • Erythrophagocytosis (engulfed RBCs)

 

 

 

 
  • 1 to 4 nucleus – Quadrinucleate
  • Thick Chromatoid body/ bar:
    • Composition: Ribonucleoprotein (RNP)
    • Stain: Iron hematoxylin

 

 

 

Entamoeba histolytica

Entamoeba coli

Trophozoite

  • Pointed pseudopodia
  • 1 nucleus
  • Central karyosome
  • Cartwheel nucleus
  • Erythrophagocytosis

Trophozoite

  • Blunt pseudopodia
  • 1 nucleus
  • Eccentric karyosome
  • No cartwheel nucleus
  • No erythrophagocytosis

Cyst

  • 1 to 4 nuclei- Quadrinucleate
  • Thick chromatoid body/bar

Cyst

  • 1 to 8 nuclei- Octanucleate
  • Thin filamentous chromatoid body/bar

 

 

Giardia lamblia (Option A): While Giardia can cause diarrhea (typically watery diarrhea), it doesn't typically cause bloody diarrhea or the same type of abdominal pain associated with Entamoeba histolytica. Giardia trophozoites would also look different under the microscope, with a characteristic "pear-shaped" appearance and two nuclei.

Shigella dysenteriae (Option B): Shigella causes bacillary dysentery, which typically presents with bloody diarrhea and severe abdominal cramping. However, the stool exam would usually show bacilli or a lack of cysts or amoeboid cells, which would be different from what is seen with Entamoeba histolytica.

Campylobacter jejuni (Option D): Campylobacter infection is another cause of diarrhea, and it is commonly associated with watery or bloody diarrhea and fever. However, it typically presents with curved rods on a stool culture, and the stool examination findings in this case would not show the characteristic cysts or trophozoites seen with Entamoeba histolytica.

questions.text: An AIDS-positive patient came with a history of fever, vomiting, and meningismus. Which of the following tests help in the rapid diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis?

choices.text: Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

Explanation:

  • Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen is a rapid, highly sensitive, and specific for cryptococcal antigen detection. It can detect antigen even before symptoms develop in AIDS patients. It is the best for rapid bedside diagnosis in resource-limited settings.

Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system

    • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection
    • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
    • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
