    • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections

 

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

    • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
    • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
    • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
    • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
    • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen- Best rapid diagnostic test.

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

 

India Ink Preparation of CSF (Option A):

  • Detects the capsulated yeast Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF.
  • Useful but low sensitivity, especially in cases with low fungal burden.

Blood Culture (Option B):

  • Can grow Cryptococcus in disseminated cases but takes several days.
  • Not a rapid diagnostic method.

CSF Culture (Option C):

  • Gold standard but time-consuming (takes 3-7 days).
  • Requires Sabouraud dextrose agar for fungal growth.

questions.text: HPV infection is most commonly associated with which type of cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Oropharyngeal cancer

Explanation:

  • HPV (especially HPV-16) is strongly associated with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (tonsil, base of tongue) and is a major causative factor for a rising subset of oropharyngeal cancers.
  • HPV is also classically linked to cervical and anogenital cancers.

Types of HPV

 

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis

 

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

Lung cancer (Option A): Primarily linked to smoking, radon, environmental factors; HPV is not a common cause.

Stomach cancer (Option C): Mainly associated with Helicobacter pylori and dietary/genetic factors.

Esophageal cancer (Option D): Risk factors include smoking, alcohol, Barrett’s oesophagus; HPV is not the typical cause.

questions.text: Which organism is most commonly responsible for gas gangrene?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Clostridium perfringens

Explanation:

  • Clostridium perfringens (especially type A strains that produce alpha toxin) is the classic cause of gas gangrene (clostridial myonecrosis)

Gas Gangrene

  • Features
    • Skin discolouration (blackish)
    • Pain
    • Discharge
    • Gas bubbles (Crepitus)
    • Shock
  • Mechanism Requires
    • Anaerobic environment
    • Contamination of wound

α-toxin/Lecithinase damages cell membranes

↓

Capillary permeability

↓

Tension in muscles

↓

Further anoxia

  • Causative factors
    • C. perfringens: 10-48 hours
    • C. septicum: 2-3 days
    • C. novyi: 5-6 days
  • Treatment
    • Surgical Debridement
    • IV Penicillin + Clindamycin for 10-14 days
    • Hyperbaric oxygen
  • Passive Immunization: Anti-gangrene serum

Clostridium difficile (Option A): Causes antibiotic-associated colitis (pseudomembranous colitis), not gas gangrene.

Clostridium tetani (Option B): Causes tetanus (neurotoxin-mediated spastic paralysis).

Clostridium botulinum (Option D): Produces botulinum toxin, causing flaccid paralysis; not gas gangrene.

questions.text: A woman was bitten by a rabid dog. The dog developed symptoms and died within a week. What is the best method for antemortem diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) DFAT

Explanation:

  • The best method for antemortem diagnosis of rabies is the DFAT (Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test).
  • In suspected rabies before death, the aim is to detect rabies virus antigen in accessible tissues/fluids.

DFAT is the gold standard antemortem test:

  • Uses fluorescent-labelled antibodies specific for rabies virus.
  • Can be done on corneal smears, nuchal skin biopsy (hair follicles), or saliva.
  • Gives rapid, sensitive, and specific results.

Detection of Negri bodies (Option A): Negri bodies (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons) are seen on histology of infected brain tissue. This is a postmortem finding, not antemortem.

Seller’s staining (Option C): Seller’s stain highlights Negri bodies in brain tissue. This is a postmortem confirmation method.

Brain biopsy (Option D): Invasive, rarely done for antemortem rabies diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was admitted with pneumonia. The microscopy shows the following image. Choose the correct organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Influenza

Explanation:

  • The given structure is identified on the basis of the enveloped, 8 segmented RNA virus, which is found in Influenza virus.

Classification:

  • Family: Orthomyxoviridae

  • Type: Enveloped virus
  • Genome: Segmented, single-stranded negative-sense RNA (–ssRNA)
  • Segments: 8 separate RNA segments (in influenza A and B; C has 7)

A. Outer Envelope

  • Derived from host cell membrane during budding.
  • Contains two major glycoprotein spikes:
    • Hemagglutinin (HA)
      • Mediates viral attachment to host cells by binding sialic acid receptors.
      • Initiates membrane fusion during viral entry.
      • Target for neutralizing antibodies.
    • Neuraminidase (NA)
      • Cleaves sialic acid residues to release newly formed virions from infected cells.
      • Target for antiviral drugs (e.g., oseltamivir, zanamivir).
  • Envelope also contains M2 ion channel protein:
    • Important for uncoating of the virus by altering pH inside the virion.

B. Matrix Layer

  • Just beneath the envelope.
  • Matrix protein M1:
    • Provides structural stability.
    • Links the envelope to the ribonucleoprotein core.

C. Ribonucleoprotein Core

  • 8 separate negative-sense RNA segments.
  • Each RNA segment is bound to nucleoprotein (NP) and RNA-dependent RNA polymerase complex:
    • PB1, PB2, PA (polymerase basic proteins).
  • Segmented genome allows genetic reassortment → basis for antigenic shift.

Special Features:

  • Segmented genome (8 pieces) → enables exchange of segments between strains → major cause of pandemics.
  • Antigenic drift: Minor changes in HA and NA due to point mutations → seasonal epidemics.
  • Antigenic shift: Major change due to reassortment of genome segments → pandemics.

 

Rotavirus (Option B): Non eveloped, 11 segmented dsRNA virus.

Hepatitis virus (Option C): None of the hepatitis virus have segmented genome. HAV (+ssRNA, non-enveloped), HBV (partially dsDNA, enveloped), HCV (+ssRNA, enveloped), HDV (–ssRNA, enveloped).

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) (Option D): Enveloped, non-segmented ssRNA virus.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was admitted with fever, headache and retro-orbital pain with rash. The tourniquet test is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dengue hemorrhagic fever

Explanation:

  • A young adult with the classic triad of fever, headache and retroorbital pain, along with rash and positive tourniquet test, suggests that the patient has acquired dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Pathophysiology in DHF

  • Caused by secondary infection with a different dengue virus serotype (DENV-1 to DENV-4).
  • Antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) leads to:
    • Increased vascular permeability.
    • Plasma leakage → hypotension/shock (Dengue shock syndrome).
    • Thrombocytopenia and bleeding tendencies.

Malaria (Option A): Presents with cyclical fevers, chills, anemia, splenomegaly.

Measles (Option B): Fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, rash starting at hairline → spreads downwards. No history of retro-orbital pain, no positive tourniquet test.

Japanese encephalitis (Option D): Arboviral disease with fever, headache, altered sensorium, seizures.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with headaches, visual disturbances, and hypertension. MRI brain shows a cerebellar hemangioblastoma, and abdominal imaging reveals multiple cysts in the kidneys along with a solid renal mass suggestive of renal cell carcinoma. His father had similar findings and died from a brain tumor in his 40s.Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Deletion on chromosome 3p

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, a hereditary condition characterised by the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys, pancreas, and other organs.
  • Genetics and pathogenesis:
    • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
    • Gene: VHL tumour suppressor
    • Chromosomal location: 3p25–26
    • Pathogenesis:
      • The VHL gene product is part of a complex that degrades hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) under normal oxygen levels.
      • Mutation or deletion → HIF is not degraded → ↑ VEGF, PDGF → abnormal angiogenesis and tumour formation.
  • Classic tumours/cysts:
    • CNS: Hemangioblastomas (esp. cerebellum, retina, spinal cord)
    • Kidneys: Simple cysts, clear cell RCC
    • Adrenal glands: Pheochromocytoma - headaches, palpitations, and sweating
    • Pancreas: Cysts, neuroendocrine tumours
    • Inner ear: Endolymphatic sac tumours

13q deletion (Option A): RB1 gene loss → retinoblastoma, osteosarcoma.

17p deletion (Option B): TP53 loss → Li-Fraumeni syndrome (sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, adrenal carcinoma).

Trisomy 12 (Option D): common cytogenetic change in CLL.

questions.text: Mutation in which of the following genes is most commonly associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) RET

Explanation:

Medullary thyroid carcinomas are associated with RET proto-oncogene mutation.

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid a neuroendocrine tumour arising from parafollicular C cells.
  • They secrete calcitonin, which regulates calcium levels and is also a marker for diagnosis and postoperative follow-up. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker in whom calcitonin is negative.
  • They can be sporadic or associated with familial syndromes like MEN 2.
  • Both have associated RET mutations.
  • Sporadic tumors usually present with solitary nodules whereas familial are characterized by bilaterality and multicentricity, and can have features of other associated tumors.
  • A biopsy would show amyloid deposits (Acal) derived from calcitonin polypeptides.

 

Thyroid Malignancy

Mutations/Genetic Alterations

Follicular Thyroid Adenoma

(Benign Condition)
  • RAS (Option A)

Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC)
  • BRAF V600E (Option B)
  • RET/PTC rearrangements

Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC)
  • RAS (Option A)
  • PAX8-PPARγ rearrangements
  • PIK3CA

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC)
  • RET (Option C)

Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma (ATC)
  • TP53 (Option D)

questions.text: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch syndrome, is caused by mutations in which type of genes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MMR

Explanation:

  • HNPCC / Lynch syndrome is caused by germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes.
  • The most commonly affected genes are:
    • MLH1
    • MSH2
    • MSH6
    • PMS2
  • Loss of these MMR proteins → failure to correct base-pairing errors → microsatellite instability (MSI) → increased risk of colorectal cancer (esp. right-sided) and extra-colonic cancers (endometrial, ovarian, gastric, urinary tract).
  • Lynch syndrome is associated with germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, leading to microsatellite instability (MSI).
  • MSI is a hallmark of Lynch syndrome-associated tumours, including colorectal adenocarcinoma.

 

APC (Option A): tumor suppressor gene mutated in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), not Lynch syndrome.

MYC (Option C): proto-oncogene involved in Burkitt lymphoma (t(8;14)), not colorectal cancer syndromes.

TERT1 (Option D): encodes telomerase reverse transcriptase; mutations linked to certain familial cancers but not HNPCC.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by his mother with irritability, poor school performance, and a history of recurrent ear infections. Otoscopic examination shows a dull, retracted tympanic membrane with fluid behind it. There is no blood clot present in the ear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Otitis media with effusion:

Explanation:

  • The key findings in this case—persistent symptoms without acute signs of infection, a dull and retracted tympanic membrane, and the presence of fluid behind the tympanic membrane without clot or acute purulence—are classic for otitis media with effusion (OME), also known as serous otitis media or glue ear. This condition is often associated with eustachian tube dysfunction, which can result from various underlying issues.

  • The most common cause of eustachian tube dysfunction in children is adenoid hyperplasia. Enlarged adenoids can obstruct the eustachian tubes, impairing the drainage of fluid from the middle ear and leading to fluid accumulation behind the tympanic membrane.

Serous Otitis Media (Glue Ear)

  • Serous Otitis Media (SOM) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of non-purulent, often thick effusion in the middle ear, commonly affecting school-aged children.

Pathogenesis:

  • The Eustachian tube fails to aerate and drain fluid from the middle ear.

  • Increased Secretory Activity of Middle Ear Mucosa.

Aetiology:

Malfunctioning of Eustachian tube

Allergy

Unresolved otitis media

Viral infections
  • Adenoid hyperplasia.
  • Chronic rhinitis and sinusitis.
  • Chronic tonsillitis: Enlarged tonsils obstruct the soft palate and affect Eustachian tube function.
  • Nasopharyngeal tumours: Benign or malignant, especially in adults with unilateral serous otitis media.
  • Palatal defects: e.g., cleft palate, palatal paralysis.
  • Down's syndrome.

Seasonal or perennial allergies obstruct the Eustachian tube and increase middle ear mucosal secretions.

Inadequate antibiotic therapy can lead to persistent, low-grade infection, stimulating more mucous production and increasing goblet cells.


Adenoviruses and rhinoviruses can invade the middle ear mucosa, leading to increased secretory activity.

Incorrect Options:

Acute otitis media (Option A): Presents with acute onset fever, ear pain, and a red bulging tympanic membrane; not a chronic, dull, retracted membrane with effusion.

Otitis externa (Option B): External ear canal infection with pain on tragal movement and canal erythema; tympanic membrane typically normal unless secondarily involved.

Cholesteatoma (Option D): Abnormal keratinizing epithelium in the middle ear, often with foul-smelling discharge and a retraction pocket; not just sterile fluid behind the membrane.

questions.text: Stapedial reflex is dependent on the integrity of which cranial nerve for its motor response?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Facial nerve (CN VII)

Explanation:

  • The stapedial reflex (acoustic reflex) is a protective middle ear reflex in which loud sounds cause contraction of the stapedius muscle to dampen ossicular movement and protect the inner ear from acoustic injury.
  • Pathway:
    • Afferent limb: Cochlea → Cochlear nerve (CN VIII) → Cochlear nucleus → Superior olivary complex.
    • Efferent limb (motor): Facial nerve (CN VII) → Stapedius muscle.
  • Clinical correlation: Lesions of the facial nerve proximal to the stapedius branch cause absent stapedial reflex and may lead to hyperacusis (increased sensitivity to sound).

Topodiagnostic tests of Facial nerve:

Test

Nerve Branch

Assessment/Outcome

Schirmer’s Test

Greater (superficial) petrosal nerve
  • A unilateral decrease in tear production (>75%) or
  • Bilateral reduction (less than 10 mm in both eyes after 5 minutes).

Stapedial Reflex

Nerve to stapedius muscle
  • Reflex is either present or absent

Electro- gustometry

Chorda tympani
  • The taste threshold is compared between the two sides to detect abnormalities

Salivary Flow Testing

Chorda tympani
  • A 25% reduction in salivary flow is considered abnormal

Incorrect Options:

Trigeminal nerve (CN V) (Option A): Motor supply to muscles of mastication; involved in the tensor tympani reflex, not the stapedius reflex.

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) (Option C): Provides sensory input to the pharynx and posterior tongue, and motor to stylopharyngeus; not involved in stapedius contraction.

Vagus nerve (CN X) (Option D): Motor supply to laryngeal and pharyngeal muscles; no role in stapedius reflex.

questions.text: A chronic smoker who worked in a cement factory for the past 20 years developed mesothelioma. This association is most likely due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Asbestosis

Explanation:

  • Mesothelioma is a malignant tumour of the pleura (and sometimes peritoneum or pericardium) that is strongly associated with asbestos exposure.

Asbestos fibres are commonly encountered in:

  • Shipbuilding
  • Construction
  • Cement manufacturing
  • Insulation materials

Chronic inhalation of asbestos fibres → fibres lodge in pleura → chronic inflammation & fibrosis → mutations → mesothelioma (and also increased risk of bronchogenic carcinoma, especially in smokers).

  • Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers.

  • Asbestos-related lung carcinoma is markedly magnified by smoking. Thus, asbestos workers (particularly those who smoke) are at much higher risk of dying of lung carcinoma than mesothelioma.
  • Compared to other occupational lung diseases, which affect the upper lobes of the lungs, it commonly affects the lower lobes.
  • Adenocarcinoma (primary bronchogenic carcinoma) is the most common type of cancer, accounting for about 45%, followed by squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following subunit is associated with inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Supraglottic:

Explanation:

Stridor is a high-pitched, harsh sound due to turbulent airflow through a partially obstructed upper airway.
Inspiratory stridor specifically occurs when obstruction is at or above the level of the vocal cords, because negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration tends to collapse the upper airway.

Supraglottic structures include:

  • Epiglottis

  • Aryepiglottic folds

  • False vocal cords

Obstruction here (e.g., epiglottitis, laryngomalacia, tumors) narrows the airway at a point where airflow is very sensitive to pressure changes during inspiration.
During inspiration → pressure above the glottis becomes subatmospheric → floppy tissue collapses inward → stridor.

Incorrect Options:

Glottic (Option A): Glottic obstruction (true vocal cords) can cause biphasic stridor (both inspiratory & expiratory), because the obstruction is fixed at the narrowest part of the larynx.

Subglottic (Option C): Subglottic narrowing (e.g., croup, subglottic stenosis) usually produces biphasic stridor as well, due to fixed airway narrowing just below the cords.

Trachea (Option D): Tracheal obstruction typically causes expiratory stridor or wheeze if intrathoracic, or biphasic if upper trachea is affected. Inspiratory-only stridor is less typical.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal discomfort. The surgical image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mature cystic teratoma

Explanation:

  • Teratomas are tumours that originate from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) and are commonly found in the ovaries.
  • They are often seen in young women and can contain a variety of tissue types, such as hair, teeth, and muscle, which reflects their origin from all three germ layers.

Mature teratoma

  • Mature teratomas, or dermoid cysts, are common benign ovarian tumours found in young women. They are bilateral in 10-15% of cases.
  • They contain tissues from all three germ layers, including skin, hair, and teeth, and can rarely undergo malignant transformation to squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Grossly, they are unilocular cysts with a thin wall and hair; microscopically, they have stratified squamous epithelium and sebaceous glands.

Immature teratoma: (Option B)

  • Bulky, solid ovarian tumours that contain immature neuroepithelium, cartilage, bone, and muscle, with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage.
  • They grow rapidly, often spreading beyond the ovary.
  • They are seen in young females and have a high risk of malignancy.
  • They have small, round blue cells (Immature neural components).

Monodermal teratoma:

  • Monodermal teratomas consist predominantly of a single type of tissue, such as thyroid tissue in struma ovarii or neuroendocrine cells in carcinoid tumours. They lack immature or embryonic-like tissues and typically do not have a high risk of malignancy.

Serous cystadenoma (Option A):

  • It is the most common ovarian epithelial tumor, usually seen in older women. It is unilocular, bilateral in >50% and is mostly malignant. The characteristic histologic feature is the presence of psamomma bodies (seen in 40-45%) which is composed of concentric rings of lamellar calcifications.

Endometrioma (Option D): “chocolate cyst” of endometriosis, filled with old blood, not sebaceous material or calcified teeth.

questions.text: Basophilic stippling of red blood cells is most characteristically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lead poisoning

Explanation:

  • Basophilic stippling is a characteristic haematological finding in lead toxicity.

Acute lead poisoning

  • It’s rare, and there may be exacerbations of chronic lead poisoning.
  • Symptoms: Astringent or metallic taste, dry throat, thirst, burning abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, peripheral circulatory collapse, paraesthesia, depression, coma, and death.

 

Chronic lead poisoning (also known as Plumbism or Saturnism)

Clinical manifestations

Description

Facial pallor

 

It is caused by vasospasm and specifically occurs circumorally, which is the earliest and most specific feature.

 

Anemia
  • Type: Microcytic-hypochromic.
  • Enzymes inhibited:
    • Ferrochelatase
    • ALA-dehydratase
    • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase

 

  • Blood picture:
    • Cabot rings in RBCs
    • Microcytic-hypochromic
    • Sideroblasts (nucleated red cells)
    • Anisocytosis
    • Poikilocytosis
    • Polycythemia

Basophilic stippling or Punctate basophilia
  • Multiple blue-coloured pinhead dots in RBCs due to the toxic action of lead on porphyrin metabolism (inhibition of enzyme 5- Pyrimidine nucleotidase) (PNN).
  • Accumulation of ribosomes in RBC

 

Lead line or Burtonian lines

The stippled blue line observed on the gums, resulting from a subepithelial deposit of granules that develops within one week, is seen in 50-70% of cases and is more common in individuals with carious teeth (bacteria form lead sulfide).

 

Lead osteopathy/Lead line (Bone-line)

In children, calcium deposition occurs at the growth plates of bones (specifically the lower end of the femur and the upper end of the tibia), which appears as a radiopaque band and occurs over 4 weeks due to the inhibition of osteoclastic activity.

 

Colic and constipation

(Painter's Colic or Devonshire colic)

Late presentation occurs in 85% of cases, typically at night, and is characterised by spasmodic pain relieved by pressure.

Lead palsy

Predominantly motor features include:

  • Dry belly ache
  • Wrist drop (Radial nerve)
  • Foot drop (Common peroneal nerve)

 

 

Encephalopathy

This condition is seen in nearly all cases, is associated with tetraethyl lead exposure, primarily affects children, results in permanent brain damage in 85% of cases, and accounts for 25% of fatalities.

Reproductive system
  • Amenorrhea
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Abortion
  • Sterility derangements (both sexes)

Cardiovascular system and Kidneys
  • Hypertension (vascular constriction)
  • Permanent arteriolar degeneration
  • Nephritis

Gout

Saturnine gout (due to decreased excretion of uric acid)

Others

These include generalised weakness, anorexia, dyspepsia, emaciation, exhaustion, irritability, foul breath, headache, vertigo, alopecia, and dizziness.

 

Conditions associated with Basophilic stippling:
  • Lead poisoning
  • Thalassemia (Beta-thalassemia)
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Arsenic poisoning
  • Alcoholism
  • Pyrimidine 5′-Nucleotidase deficiency
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Severe infections (e.g., malaria)
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Chronic inflammatory conditions

 

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option A): microcytic hypochromic cells, but no basophilic stippling.

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option C): macrocytosis with hypersegmented neutrophils, no stippling.

Hereditary spherocytosis (Option D): spherocytes, increased MCHC, but no stippling.

questions.text: In Pap smear cytology, which of the following is the most appropriate fixative used to preserve cellular details immediately after smearing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 95% ethanol

Explanation:

  • 95% ethanol is the fixative used in a conventional pap smear.

Fixatives are chemicals that preserve biological tissues by stabilizing cellular structures and preventing decay or degradation. The goal is to maintain the tissue in a life-like state as much as possible for microscopic examination.

  • Fixation helps maintain the tissue's integrity by preventing autolysis (self-digestion) and putrefaction (bacterial decay).
  • Crosslinking Fixatives: These fixatives work by forming covalent bonds between the proteins and other cellular structures, effectively "locking" them in place. This preserves the tissue’s structural integrity.
    • Formaldehyde: Most commonly used in the form of 10% neutral-buffered formalin. (Option D)
    • Glutaraldehyde: Often used for electron microscopy due to its ability to preserve fine cellular structures.
    • Osmium tetroxide: Used primarily for electron microscopy, particularly for preserving lipids and membranes.
  • Precipitating Fixatives: These work by precipitating proteins and other cellular components, which makes them less soluble and helps preserve their structure.
    • Methanol
    • Ethanol
  • Additive Fixatives: They chemically bind to tissue components, such as proteins or nucleic acids, and stabilise them. They are typically more gentle and produce better preservation of ultrastructure.
    • Formaldehyde (Option A)
    • Glutaraldehyde
  • Non-Additive Fixatives:
    • Alcohol
    • Acetone

Pap smear

Site
  • The transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.
  • This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop.

Instruments
  • Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix
  • Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from the transition zone
  • Endocervical brush from the endocervix

Procedure
  • Conventional Pap smear: Cells are collected with a spatula or brush, smeared onto a slide, and immediately fixed with a spray fixative or by immersing in 95% ethanol with/without ether
  • Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with short stature. On evaluation, the bone age is found to be less than the chronological age. There are no dysmorphic features, and the child is otherwise healthy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Constitutional delay of growth and puberty:

Explanation: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP) is the most common cause of short stature in otherwise healthy children. It is characterized by:

  • Normal birth length and weight
  • Slowing of growth velocity during early childhood
  • Bone age delayed compared to chronological age
  • No dysmorphic features
  • Normal growth potential — eventual catch-up and normal adult height
  • Often a family history of “late bloomers”

Incorrect Options:

Familial short stature (Option B): Bone age is typically equal to chronological age; height is short but consistent with genetic potential.

Achondroplasia (Option C): Disproportionate short stature with rhizomelia (short limbs), frontal bossing, and characteristic facies.

Chondrodysplasia (Option D): A group of genetic disorders causing disproportionate short stature and skeletal abnormalities, usually evident early and with bone deformities.

questions.text: A newborn, born to a diabetic mother, presents after 24 hours of life with a blood glucose level of <35 mg/dL. The baby is symptomatic. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Administer IV bolus of Hartmann solution
Administer IV glucose and recheck blood glucose after 20 minutes

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Administer IV glucose and recheck blood glucose after 20 minutes:

Explanation: In a symptomatic newborn with blood glucose <35 mg/dL, immediate correction is necessary to prevent seizures and brain injury. The standard approach is:

  • Give an IV bolus of 10% dextrose (2 mL/kg)
  • Follow with a continuous glucose infusion (usually 6–8 mg/kg/min)
  • Recheck glucose after 20–30 minutes to ensure correction

This is particularly important in infants of diabetic mothers, who are at high risk for hypoglycemia due to persistent fetal hyperinsulinism after birth.

Management of Hypoglycemia in neonates:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Administer IV bolus of Hartmann solution (Option A): Does not contain glucose; ineffective for treating hypoglycemia.

Recheck blood glucose after 20 minutes (Option B): Delaying treatment in a symptomatic neonate risks neurological injury.

Start oral feeds and observe (Option D): Only appropriate for asymptomatic mild hypoglycemia; symptomatic cases require IV therapy.

questions.text: Which genetic syndrome is caused by a deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cri-du-chat syndrome:

Explanation: Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion). The name “cri-du-chat” (French for “cry of the cat”) refers to the characteristic high-pitched, cat-like cry of affected infants due to laryngeal hypoplasia and abnormal development of the nervous system.

  • Other features include microcephaly, hypertelorism, epicanthal folds, hypotonia, developmental delay, and severe intellectual disability.

Incorrect Options:

Edward syndrome (Option A): Caused by trisomy 18, not 5p deletion.

Patau syndrome (Option B): Caused by trisomy 13, not 5p deletion.

Turner syndrome (Option D): Caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome (45,XO), not 5p deletion.

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the clinic for developmental assessment. On examination, he has a prominent epicanthal fold, a single transverse palmar crease, hypotonia, and intellectual disability. Facial features appear flat with upslanting palpebral fissures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Down syndrome

Explanation: Down syndrome is caused by trisomy 21 and is the most common chromosomal cause of intellectual disability.

Down's syndrome, caused by trisomy 21, is associated with multiple systemic manifestations due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21.

  • This is due to meiotic nondisjunction in either maternal or paternal gamete.

  • Occurs at a frequency of 1:800 to 1:1000 newborns.

The overexpression of genes located on chromosome 21 contributes to the clinical features.

Clinical Features and Diagnosis:

General Features:

  • Intellectual disability

  • Flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes with epicanthic folds, oblique palpebral fissure (visible when eyes are open).

  • Small nose with flat nasal bridge

  • Narrow palate, small teeth, and furrowed, protruding tongue

  • Significant hypotonia

  • Small, brachycephalic skull with flat occiput, and small, dysplastic ears

  • Short, broad hands with clinodactyly (hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the fifth finger)

  • Simian crease on the palm

  • A wide gap between the first and second toes (sandal gap)

Comorbidities

  • Congenital Heart Disease:: 40% of children have congenital heart defects, primarily endocardial cushion defects (40-60% of cases) - AVSD, VSD, ASD, PDA, TOF. Early cardiac evaluation is crucial.

  • Gastrointestinal Malformations: 12% have atresias, especially duodenal atresia. There is an increased risk of annular pancreas and Hirschsprung disease.

  • Ophthalmic Problems: Increased risk of cataracts, nystagmus, strabismus, and visual acuity issues. Regular eye evaluations are advised from infancy onward.

  • Hearing Defects: 40-60% experience conductive hearing loss, often due to serous otitis media in the first year. Routine hearing assessments are recommended before 6 months of age and annually.

  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Hypothyroidism occurs in 13-54% of patients.

  • Atlanto-occipital Subluxation: Incidence ranges from 10-30%. A lateral neck radiograph is recommended.

  • Physical Growth: Linear growth is typically slower, and children may become obese with age. Muscle tone often improves, but regular monitoring of height and weight is necessary.

  • Malignancies: Increased risk of lymphoproliferative disorders, such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia, and transient lymphoproliferative syndrome.

  • Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease: The APP gene, located on chromosome 21, plays a significant role in amyloid plaque formation, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

Incorrect Options:

Patau syndrome (Option B): Caused by trisomy 13; associated with cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, microphthalmia, and holoprosencephaly, not the described features.

Edward syndrome (Option C): Caused by trisomy 18; features include clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, micrognathia, and severe growth restriction.

Fragile X syndrome (Option D): X-linked condition with intellectual disability, macroorchidism, long narrow face, and large ears. But, lacks the facial features and palmar crease of Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child weighs 40 kg and presents with mental retardation. On examination, the upper segment to lower segment (US:LS) ratio is 1.1:1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rickets

Explanation: In a 10-year-old, the normal upper segment to lower segment (US:LS) ratio is about 0.9:1 (lower segment longer than upper segment due to leg growth).

  • A higher US:LS ratio (e.g., 1.1:1) means the upper segment is disproportionately longer, suggesting shortening of the lower segment — commonly due to rickets or other conditions affecting long bone growth.
  • Rickets in childhood causes defective mineralization of bone, leading to limb deformities and disproportionate short stature.

Incorrect Options:

Cretinism (Option A): Causes proportionate dwarfism, not a disproportionate US:LS ratio; also presents earlier with severe developmental delay, coarse facies.

Achondroplasia (Option C): Produces rhizomelic limb shortening from birth, with US:LS ratio much higher (~1.5:1), and characteristic facial features.

Hypothyroidism (Option D): Causes proportionate short stature unless associated with bone dysplasia; also presents with other features like bradycardia, lethargy, delayed reflexes.

questions.text: FBN1 gene mutation is seen in which of the following genetic disorders?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Marfan syndrome

Explanation:

  • Marfan syndrome is commonly associated with mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes the connective protein fibrillin on chromosome 15q21.

Pathophysiology:

  • Abnormal fibrillin-1 → defective microfibrils → weakened elastic fibres.
  • This leads to increased TGF-β activity, which contributes to the characteristic features of the syndrome.

Mode of inheritance:

  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Multisystem disorder with involvement of the connective tissues.

Clinical features:

Skeletal abnormalities:
  • Tall, thin build with long limbs (dolichostenomelia)
  • Arachnodactyly
  • Chest wall abnormalities like pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum
  • Thumb sign( On folding the thumb, it will protrude beyond the ulnar border of palm) or wrist sign is positive
  • Increased joint laxity
  • Scoliosis

CVS abnormalities:
  • Aortic root dilation → aortic regurgitation
  • Risk of aortic aneurysm and dissection
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Arrhythmias

Eye abnormalities:

 
  • Ectopia lentis or subluxation of the lens of the eye
  • Blindness, Myopia

Pulmonary involvement:

  • Increased risk of pneumothorax

Diagnosis:

  • Marfan syndrome is clinically diagnosed using the Ghent criteria

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (Option A): Usually due to collagen synthesis defects (type III or type V collagen), not FBN1.

Homocystinuria (Option C): Due to cystathionine β-synthase deficiency → high homocysteine levels; may have marfanoid habitus but with downward lens dislocation and thrombosis risk.

Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (Option D): Due to VHL gene mutation on chromosome 3p, not FBN1; characterized by hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas.

questions.text: A mutation in the SOD1 gene is most commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

Explanation:

  • The SOD1 gene encodes superoxide dismutase 1, an enzyme responsible for breaking down harmful superoxide radicals into oxygen and hydrogen peroxide. This protects cells from oxidative damage.

SOD1 and ALS:

  • Condition: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease.
  • Type: SOD1 mutations account for about 20% of familial ALS cases (familial ALS ~10% of all ALS cases).
  • Mechanism:
    • Mutant SOD1 misfolds → gains toxic properties → causes oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction.
    • This leads to degeneration of both upper motor neurons (in motor cortex) and lower motor neurons (in brainstem and spinal cord).

Clinical Features of ALS:

  • Mixed UMN and LMN signs:
    • UMN: Spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign.
    • LMN: Fasciculations, muscle atrophy, weakness.
  • Progressive, usually fatal within 3–5 years (respiratory failure common).
  • Sensation and cognition are usually preserved (helps differentiate from MS or other neuropathies).

Huntington’s disease (Option A): CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene (chromosome 4).

Multiple sclerosis (Option B): Autoimmune demyelination, not linked to SOD1.

Parkinson's disease (Option C): Often linked to mutations in SNCA, LRRK2, PARK genes, not SOD1.

questions.text: Blood transfusion reactions are mediated by which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type II

Explanation:

  • Blood transfusion reactions (specifically acute hemolytic transfusion reactions) occur when the recipient’s immune system attacks donor red blood cells due to ABO incompatibility.

Mechanism:

  • Type of hypersensitivity: Type II (antibody-mediated cytotoxic).
  • Pathophysiology:
    1. Pre-existing IgM antibodies in the recipient bind to antigens (A or B) on donor RBCs.
    2. This activates the complement cascade, leading to:
      • RBC lysis (intravascular hemolysis)
      • Release of haemoglobin
      • Inflammatory cytokine release
    3. Clinical presentation: fever, chills, hypotension, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, possible DIC.

Type I (Option A): IgE-mediated (allergies, anaphylaxis).

Type III (Option C): Immune complex–mediated (e.g., serum sickness, post-strep GN).

Type IV (Option D): T-cell–mediated (delayed, e.g., TB skin test, contact dermatitis).

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with history of multiple sexual partners presented with anorexia and jaundice. The biopsy shows ground-glass opacity in the cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hepatitis B

  • This clinical scenario of a male with a promiscuous sexual history and ground-glass opacities on biopsy points to Hepatitis B infection.
  • In chronic Hepatitis B infection, hepatocytes can appear pale and finely granular on histology, called ground-glass hepatocytes.
  • This appearance is due to the accumulation of Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) within the endoplasmic reticulum of infected hepatocytes.
  • Common in chronic carriers and chronic hepatitis B patients.
  • Risk factor- Multiple sexual partners, high risk of sexually transmitted infections, including HBV.

Hepatitis A (Option A):

  • Feco–oral transmission (contaminated food/water), not sexually transmitted in most cases.
  • Does not produce ground-glass hepatocytes.
  • Histology: hepatocyte ballooning degeneration, Councilman bodies in acute hepatitis.

Hepatitis C (Option C):

  • Transmitted mainly via blood (IV drug use, transfusions).
  • Histology shows lymphoid aggregates in portal tracts, steatosis, and no ground-glass appearance.

Hepatitis D (Option D: Histology changes depend on concurrent HBV changes; ground-glass cells still come from the HBV component.)

questions.text: A diabetic male presented with seizures. Radiological examination shows a lesion. Histopathological examination shows liquefactive necrosis. What is the most important mechanism responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Enzymatic degradation.

Explanation:

  • Diabetic patient with seizures → raises suspicion for a brain lesion (possibly abscess, infarct, or infection-related pathology).
  • Histopathology: liquefactive necrosis → classic type of necrosis seen in brain tissue.
  • Liquefactive necrosis in brain is mainly due to hydrolytic enzyme action breaking down tissue.
  • In the CNS, ischemia or infection activates microglia and infiltrating neutrophils.
  • These cells release lysosomal hydrolytic enzymes.
  • Brain tissue is rich in lipids and has little structural stroma, so enzymatic digestion quickly converts tissue into a liquid mass.
  • Mechanism: enzymatic degradation > structural breakdown → liquefactive necrosis.

Mechanical (Option B): Trauma can cause hemorrhage or contusion, but necrosis type is not primarily from mechanical injury alone, here histology points to enzymatic breakdown.

Ischemic (Option C): Ischemia in most organs causes coagulative necrosis, except in the brain, where it still leads to liquefactive necrosis, but the mechanism is enzymatic digestion, not ischemia per se.

Pressure (Option D): Increased intracranial pressure can cause herniation or atrophy, not liquefactive necrosis by itself.

questions.text: What is the eye manifestation seen in HLA B27-positive patients with ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Uveitis

  • Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) with possible extraintestinal manifestations.
  • HLA-B27–positive patients have a higher risk of certain autoimmune complications, particularly in the eye.
  • The most classic ocular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis.

Features of uveitis in HLA-B27–associated IBD:

  • Usually unilateral, sudden onset.
  • Symptoms: eye pain, redness, photophobia, blurred vision.
  • Exam: ciliary flush, cells & flare in anterior chamber.
  • Can be recurrent.

Conjunctivitis (Option B): It is more common in reactive arthritis (Reiter’s syndrome), not as strong an association with ulcerative colitis. Conjunctivitis involves superficial eye redness without the deep inflammation of uveitis.

Scleritis (Option C): Deep, boring eye pain; associated with systemic autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis. It is less commonly seen in ulcerative colitis.

Iridocyclitis (Option D): refers to inflammation of the iris and ciliary body (a subset of anterior uveitis).

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with enuresis (bedwetting). The parents mention the child had a fall from bed once, but has no other significant medical history. There are no signs of urinary tract infection or neurological deficits. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Behavioral modification:

Explanation: In an 8-year-old with primary nocturnal enuresis (bedwetting since birth) and no evidence of urinary tract infection, neurological abnormality, or daytime symptoms, the first-line management is non-pharmacological behavioral measures. These include:

  • Limiting evening fluid intake
  • Scheduled voiding before bedtime
  • Positive reinforcement and reward systems
  • Enuresis alarms if behavioral methods alone are insufficient

Pharmacological therapy like desmopressin or oxybutynin is reserved for cases where behavioral measures fail, or when there is a need for rapid short-term control (e.g., sleepovers, camps).

Incorrect Options:

Start anticholinergic drugs (Option B): Used mainly for urge incontinence or overactive bladder, not first-line for primary nocturnal enuresis.

Prescribe oxybutynin (Option C): An anticholinergic; indicated for detrusor overactivity, not for initial management of simple nocturnal enuresis.

Start desmopressin therapy (Option D): Mimics ADH to reduce urine production at night; second-line after behavioral measures fail.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with exertional dyspnea and a history of cyanotic spells. On examination, there is clubbing and a harsh systolic murmur heard at the left upper sternal border. Chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tetralogy of Fallot

Explanation: The child presents with cyanotic spells, exertional dyspnea, and clubbing, all classic signs of a cyanotic congenital heart disease.

  • A harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border is most consistent with right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (pulmonary stenosis) in Tetralogy of Fallot.

Components of Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Pulmonary Stenosis:
    • Narrowing of the pathway from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery, possibly affecting the infundibulum, valve, or main pulmonary artery.
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD):
    • A large hole between the right and left ventricles, usually misaligned, allowing abnormal blood flow.
  • Overriding Aorta:
    • The aorta is positioned over the septum, receiving blood from both ventricles.
  • Right Ventricular Hypertrophy:
    • Thickening of the right ventricle wall due to the extra effort required to pump blood.

Incorrect Options:

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (Option B): Classically shows a “snowman” or “figure-of-eight” appearance on X-ray, not boot-shaped heart.

Transposition of the Great Arteries (Option C): Chest X-ray may show an “egg-on-a-string” appearance; cyanosis appears in the first days of life, not typically at age 5.

Atrial Septal Defect (Option D): Usually acyanotic; X-ray shows cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings, not boot-shaped heart.

questions.text: On January 1, 2024, an area with a population of 10,000 had 100 TB cases. During the year, 30 patients were cured and 10 died. Twenty new TB cases were reported, and 5 of them were cured before December 31, 2024. What is the incidence and prevalence of TB cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. 2 and 1.2

Explanation:

  • Incidence (new cases during the year) and prevalence (total cases at a specific point in time, here end of year):

Incidence:

  • Population at risk = Total population − existing cases on Jan 1 = 10,000 − 100 = 9,900
  • New TB cases during 2024 = 20
  • Incidence per 1,000 = (20 ÷ 9,900) × 1,000 = ≈ 2 per 1,000

Prevalence (Dec 31, 2024):

  • Remaining old cases = 100 − (30 cured + 10 died) = 60
  • Remaining new cases = 20 − 5 cured = 15
  • Total existing cases on Dec 31 = 60 + 15 = 75
  • Prevalence (%) = (75 ÷ 10,000) × 100 = 0.75% ≈ 1.2%

Term

Definition

Formula

Incidence

New cases during a defined period among at-risk population

(New cases ÷ Population at risk) × Multiplier

Prevalence

All existing cases (old + new) at a point in time

(All cases ÷ Total population) × Multiplier
  • Incidence → measures risk of developing disease.
  • Prevalence → measures burden of disease.

1.2 and 10 (Option B) – Incidence is not 1.2 per 1,000 here; prevalence is not 10%.

1.2 and 12 (Option C) – Neither matches the calculated values.

2 and 10 (Option D) – Incidence matches, but prevalence is not 10%, it’s about 1.2%.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered harmful to a newborn baby in the immediate postnatal period?

choices.text: Cleaning the eyes with a wet sterile swab
Giving a bath immediately after birth
Placing the baby on the mother's chest

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Giving a bath immediately after birth

Explanation: Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is harmful because it:

  • Causes hypothermia due to rapid heat loss
  • Delays skin-to-skin contact and early initiation of breastfeeding
  • Increases the risk of respiratory distress in a cold-stressed baby
  • Removes the vernix caseosa, which has protective antimicrobial and moisturizing properties

WHO recommends delaying the first bath for at least 24 hours after birth (or at least 6 hours if cultural reasons necessitate earlier bathing).

Incorrect Options:

Cleaning the eyes with a wet sterile swab (Option A): Safe and part of immediate newborn care to prevent infection.

Initiating breastfeeding within 1 hour (Option C): Beneficial for immunity, bonding, and reducing neonatal mortality.

Placing the baby on the mother's chest (Option D): Encourages warmth, bonding, and early feeding.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with a respiratory rate of 66 breaths per minute, along with chest indrawing and nasal flaring. There are no other significant findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumonia

Explanation: In infants aged 2–12 months, WHO IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) classifies:

  • Pneumonia: Cough or difficulty breathing with fast breathing (≥50 breaths/min in 2–12 months) without danger signs.
  • Severe pneumonia: Cough or difficulty breathing plus any danger sign (e.g., chest indrawing with general danger signs such as inability to feed, lethargy, convulsions, hypoxia).

Classification

Signs

Treatment

Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

Any general danger sign

OR

  • Oxygen saturation <90%
  • Stridor in calm child
  • Central cyanosis
  • Convulsions
  • AVPU = V, P, or U
  • Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.
  • Administer Benzyl Penicillin & Gentamicin.
  • Give diazepam if convulsing.
  • Prevent low blood sugar.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Urgent referral or admission.

Pneumonia

Chest indrawing in calm child

OR

Fast breathing

AND

No signs of severe pneumonia
  • Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablet.
  • Give Vitamin A.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Follow up in 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

No Pneumonia: Cough or Cold

No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease
  • Treat wheeze if present - salbutamol for 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

In this case:

  • Age = 4 months (threshold for tachypnea ≥50/min; child has 66/min).
  • Signs = Chest indrawing, nasal flaring, but no danger signs like inability to feed, cyanosis, altered consciousness.
    • Fits pneumonia classification, not severe pneumonia.

Incorrect Options:

Severe pneumonia (Option B): Requires danger signs or hypoxia; not present here.

Severe asthma (Option C): Rare in infants; asthma usually diagnosed in older children with recurrent wheezing.

Common cold (Option D): No tachypnea or significant respiratory distress.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with high conjugated (direct) bilirubin, dark-colored urine, and clay-colored stools. On examination, the infant appears jaundiced, but is feeding normally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Biliary atresia

Explanation: Biliary atresia typically presents in the first 2–6 weeks of life with:

  • Conjugated (direct) hyperbilirubinemia
  • Clay-colored stools (due to lack of bile pigments in intestine)
  • Dark urine (due to excretion of conjugated bilirubin in urine)
  • Baby usually feeds well initially and appears otherwise healthy, but progressive jaundice is noted.

Incorrect Options:

Gilbert’s syndrome (Option B): Causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, usually mild, and presents later in childhood or adolescence.

Crigler–Najjar syndrome (Option C): Severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to absent (Type I) or deficient (Type II) UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity; presents in the first days of life with kernicterus risk, not with pale stools.

Physiological jaundice (Option D): Common in newborns, peaks at day 3–5, and is unconjugated; stools and urine remain normal in color.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of jaundice in this newborn presenting with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, intrahepatic cholestasis, high alkaline phosphatase, and the presence of eosinophilic, PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules in liver biopsy specimens, suggestive of Alpha 1 AT deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neonatal hepatitis

Explanation:

Neonatal hepatitis:

Neonatal hepatitis is inflammation of the liver that occurs in newborn infants. It can be caused by various factors, including viral infections (such as hepatitis viruses), metabolic disorders, genetic conditions, and drug-induced liver injury.

In the given scenario, the presentation indicative of neonatal hepatitis includes:

  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
  • Intrahepatic cholestasis
  • High alkaline phosphatase,
  • Presence of eosinophilic PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules on liver biopsy

Incorrect Options:

Hypoplasia of biliary tract (Option A): Hypoplasia of the biliary tract refers to underdevelopment or incomplete formation of the bile ducts. It presents with pale stools and bile duct proliferation on biopsy, and can lead to impaired bile flow and subsequent cholestasis. However, it is not the most common cause of jaundice in the neonates.

Choledochal cyst (Option C) : A choledochal cyst is a congenital anomaly characterized by dilatation of the bile ducts. It can cause bile flow obstruction and subsequently leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, jaundice and an abdominal mass due to bile duct dilation. Unlike A1AT deficiency, it shows extrahepatic obstruction on imaging and lacks PAS-positive inclusions.

Physiological (Option D): Physiological jaundice, is a normal and temporary condition that occurs in many newborns due to the immature liver's ability to process bilirubin efficiently. It presents with unconjugated bilirubinemia, not conjugated.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent sinusitis and repeated lung infections. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the CFTR gene. Which test is considered the gold standard to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sweat chloride test:

Explanation: The child’s recurrent sinusitis, repeated lung infections, and confirmed CFTR gene mutation are suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF).

  • The gold standard diagnostic test for CF is the quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis sweat chloride test.

Cystic Fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease that can be detected via sweat chloride test in newborns.

  • Pancreatic insufficiency is seen in more than 85% of children with CF and leads to malabsorption, resulting in symptoms like failure to thrive, frequent greasy stools, and weight gain difficulties.

Clinical Features of Cystic Fibrosis by Age Group

Age Group

Sinopulmonary

Gastrointestinal

Renal, Endocrine, Other

Infancy
  • Infection
  • Fetal echogenic bowel
  • Meconium ileus
  • Pancreatic insufficiency
  • Rectal prolapse
  • Dehydration
  • Hyponatremic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis

Childhood
  • Infection
  • ABPA
  • Polyposis
  • Sinusitis
  • DIOS (Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome)
  • Intussusception
  • Hepatic steatosis, biliary fibrosis
  • Rectal prolapse
  • Renal calculi
  • Hyponatremic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis

Adolescence/Adulthood
  • Infection
  • ABPA
  • Haemoptysis
  • Pneumothorax
  • Respiratory failure
  • Sinusitis, Polyposis, Anosmia
  • DIOS
  • Intussusception
  • Biliary fibrosis, cirrhosis
  • Digestive tract cancer (adenocarcinoma)
  • Delayed puberty, osteoporosis, CFRD (Cystic Fibrosis-Related Diabetes)
  • Renal calculi, renal failure
  • CBAVD (Congenital Bilateral Absence of the Vas Deferens), HPOA (Hypertrophic Pulmonary Osteoarthropathy)
  • Arthritis, vasculitis
  • Hyponatremic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis

Diagnostic Criteria

Requirement

Any ONE of the following:

Clinical Features

Presence of typical features (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary)

Family History

A sibling with diagnosed cystic fibrosis

Newborn Screening Test
  • Positive result indicating risk for cystic fibrosis
  • Immunoreactive trypsinogen (IRT) is the first-line screen, which identifies babies with pancreatic insufficiency, one of the hallmarks of CF.

PLUS at least ONE:

Laboratory Evidence of CFTR Dysfunction
  • Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations on separate days
  • Pilocarpine iontophoresis: Used to diagnose cystic fibrosis in infants by estimating sweat chloride ion levels; elevated chloride levels (≥60 mMol/L) in sweat are indicative of the condition.
  • Identification of two CFTR mutations
  • An abnormal nasal potential difference measurement

Incorrect Options:

Lung biopsy (Option B): Rarely indicated; not used for diagnosis of CF.

Chest X-ray (Option C): May show bronchiectasis or hyperinflation but is nonspecific.

Nasal swab culture (Option D): May detect organisms like Pseudomonas aeruginosa, but does not confirm CF.

questions.text: In which of the following should a cotton swab with pus be discarded?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Yellow non-chlorination bag

Explanation:

Cotton swab with pus = soiled waste (items contaminated with blood, body fluids, pus, etc.).

  • Soiled waste → Yellow category (non-chlorinated plastic bags).
  • Chlorination is avoided for biodegradable waste like cotton, gauze, bandages, etc., as these are incinerated.

Biomedical Waste Management Summary

  • Fetus, organ, tissue, soiled cotton, gauze, dressing, bandages, casts, plasters, IUD, expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic waste, body secretions e.g. sputum, pus, feces, X-ray developer fluids, disinfectants, linens, beddings, mattress, gowns, culture plates, blood bags, blood transfusion sets, live vaccine vial, blood products, masks, shoe cover, head cover: Yellow bag for incineration, plasma pyrolysis, and deep burial.
  • Recyclable plastics, tubes, vacutainers without blood, syringes without needles, urobags, catheters, Ryle's tubes, IV drip sets, face shields, goggles: Red bag.
  • Sharps and other metals: White bag.
  • Orthopaedic implants, glassware, artificial pacemaker: Blue bag.

Yellow chlorination bag (Option A): Not used; yellow category waste is incinerated, so chlorination is unnecessary.

Red chlorination bag (Option C): The red category is for contaminated recyclable waste (e.g., tubing, catheters), not soiled waste.

Red non-chlorination bag (Option D): Still incorrect category for pus-soaked cotton.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with leg deformities and skeletal abnormalities. On examination, he is using crutches and has visible bowing of the legs. It is also noted that several other villagers exhibit similar symptoms. Considering the cluster of cases in the same geographic area, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the investigation?

choices.text: Collect and analyze water samples for fluoride content

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Collect and analyze water samples for fluoride content

Explanation:

  • A cluster of similar skeletal deformities in people from the same village suggests an environmental cause rather than an individual nutritional or endocrine disorder. Endemic skeletal fluorosis from high fluoride levels in drinking water causes bowing of legs, bone pain, and deformities. Therefore, the most logical next step is testing the local water supply for fluoride concentration.

Endemic fluorosis:

  • Caused by long-term ingestion of water with fluoride >1.5 mg/L.
  • Early signs: joint stiffness, dental fluorosis.
  • Late signs: bony overgrowths, deformities, restricted movements.
  • Prevention: defluoridation of water, alternative safe water sources.

Check serum vitamin D levels (Option A): Could detect rickets/osteomalacia, but wouldn’t explain a cluster in the same area.

Measure serum calcium levels (Option B): Useful for metabolic bone diseases, but not the primary step in an environmental cluster investigation.

Perform parathyroid hormone (PTH) assay (Option C): For hyper/hypoparathyroidism; not first-line in a suspected environmental outbreak.

questions.text: A teenage boy, who was previously raised as a girl, presents with primary amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual characteristics. On examination, he has tall stature, small testes, and gynecomastia. Testosterone level was normal. Which of the following is the most likely genotype?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 47,XXY:

Explanation: The presentation fits Klinefelter syndrome, a condition with 47,XXY karyotype.

Key features include:

  • Genotypic male but with small, firm testes and primary testicular failure
  • Tall stature with disproportionately long limbs
  • Gynecomastia and sparse facial/body hair
  • Often detected at puberty due to delayed secondary sexual characteristics or infertility
  • Testosterone may be in the low–normal range due to Leydig cell dysfunction, with elevated gonadotropins (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism)

Incorrect Options:

45,X (Option A): Turner syndrome - short stature, streak gonads, female phenotype.

46,XX (Option B): Normal female karyotype, not consistent with male phenotype.

47,XYY (Option D): Tall males with normal fertility; usually asymptomatic or may have learning difficulties.

questions.text: A patient presents with increased consumption of Bajra (pearl millet) roti and now complains of drowsiness and giddiness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Ergotism

Explanation:

  • Bajra (pearl millet) can be contaminated with Claviceps purpurea (ergot fungus), which produces ergot alkaloids. These alkaloids cause vasoconstriction and may lead to symptoms like giddiness, drowsiness, tingling, and, in severe cases, gangrene or convulsions. Ergotism is classically linked to the consumption of contaminated grains like millet, rye, or sorghum.

Food intoxicants:

Condition

Toxin

Food Source

Prevention

Neurolathyrism

Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)

Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal/grass pea)

Vitamin C, steeping, parboiling

Endemic Ascites

Pyrrolizidine alkaloids

Contaminated cereals with Crotalaria seeds

Avoid contaminated grains

Epidemic Dropsy

Sanguinarine

Mustard oil adulterated with Argemone oil

Pre-testing (Nitric acid chromatography test), De-weeding

Aflatoxicosis

Aflatoxin B₁

Mouldy groundnuts, maize

Proper drying & storage

Ergotism

Ergot alkaloids

Rye, bajra, wheat with ergot fungus

Floating plant in 20% salt solution

Epidemic dropsy (Option A): Caused by Argemone mexicana contamination of mustard oil → edema, diarrhea, cardiac failure; not related to Bajra.

Botulism (Option C): Caused by Clostridium botulinum toxin from improperly canned food → descending flaccid paralysis, not drowsiness from grain consumption.

Fusarium toxicity (Option D): From Fusarium fungi → alimentary toxic aleukia with pancytopenia; not typically linked to Bajra in this presentation.

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-month-old baby, concerned that no BCG scar has appeared, although the baby received the BCG vaccine at birth. What is the next best step?

choices.text: Do the Mantoux test & wait for the result
Refer the baby for a chest X-ray & further evaluation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Reassure the mother

Explanation:

  • After BCG vaccination, some children may not develop a visible scar, even though they have adequate immunity. No BCG scar is not an indication for revaccination if the child is otherwise healthy. WHO and national immunization guidelines recommend no further action in such cases- simply reassure the caregiver.

BCG Vaccine

  • Type: Live attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis
  • Schedule: Single dose at birth (or as early as possible till 1 year of age)
  • Dose & route: 0.05 mL (infants <1 yr), 0.1 mL (≥1 yr) — intradermal, left upper arm
  • Purpose: Protection against severe forms of childhood TB (TB meningitis, miliary TB)
  • Contraindications: Symptomatic HIV infection, immunodeficiency, pregnancy, generalized skin disease
  • Storage: Lyophilized form at 2–8 °C; reconstituted vaccine stable for 3–4 hours only
  • Adverse events: Local ulcer at site, regional lymphadenitis, keloid (rare)
  • Coverage target: Universal Immunization Programme (UIP)

Give the BCG vaccine immediately (Option B): Revaccination is not recommended; lack of scar doesn’t mean lack of immunity.

Do Mantoux test & wait for the result (Option C): Not required in an asymptomatic, healthy, vaccinated child.

Refer for chest X-ray & further evaluation (Option D): Only indicated if there are clinical features suggestive of TB.

questions.text: Out of the MR & Pentavalent vaccine, which can be reused, and which one should be discarded when the vial is opened according to the open vial policy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Discard MR, reuse Pentavalent

Explanation:

Open Vial Policy (WHO guidelines) allows certain multi-dose vials to be reused for up to 28 days after opening if:

  • They have no preservative contamination.
  • They are kept under proper cold chain conditions (2–8 °C).

Pentavalent vaccine → liquid formulation with preservative → can be reused until expiry within the 28-day rule.

MR (Measles-Rubella) vaccine → lyophilized (freeze-dried) powder without preservative, reconstituted with diluent before use → must be discarded within 4 hours of reconstitution, irrespective of remaining doses.

Open Vial Policy:

  • Allows certain vaccines to be used in multiple immunization sessions after opening the vial, if stored and handled properly. If the vaccine is under the open vial policy then VVM will bw on the body (not on cap/neck).

Purpose:

  • Reduce vaccine wastage
  • Ensure uninterrupted immunization services
  • Lower programme costs without compromising safety.

The vaccine can be kept and used for up to 28 days after opening only if:

  • Vaccine is WHO-prequalified for MDVP use
  • Vaccine vial is kept at recommended storage temperature (+2°C to +8°C)
  • VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor) has not crossed discard point
  • Expiry date has not passed
  • Aseptic technique used every time vial is opened
  • Reconstituted vaccines (like BCG, Measles, MR, JE) must be discarded within 6 hours or at the end of the session — no exception.

Vaccines NOT under Open Vial Policy:

  • BCG
  • Measles / MR
  • COVID 19 (use within 8 hours)

Discard Pentavalent, reuse MR (Option B): Wrong - MR cannot be used after 4 hous of reconstitution, so it must be discarded.

Discard both MR and Pentavalent (Option C): Wrong - Pentavalent can be reused if stored properly.

Reuse both MR and Pentavalent (Option D): Wrong - MR cannot be reused after 4 hours of reconstitution.

questions.text: Which among the following logos will be seen in a contaminated biomedical waste management plant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Biohazard symbol

Explanation:

  • A contaminated biomedical waste management plant handles infectious and hazardous materials → marked with the biohazard logo
  • This symbol is internationally recognized for infectious agents and materials that pose a threat to humans or the environment.

Universal recycling symbol (Option B): Used for recyclable materials, not related to infectious waste.

Radiation hazard symbol (Option C): Indicates radioactive materials

High voltage symbol (Option D): Warns of electrical hazards, not used for waste categorization.

questions.text: In a group, the mean blood glucose level is 105 mg/dL with a standard deviation of 10 mg/dL. Assuming a normal distribution, what is the expected range of blood glucose values for approximately 95% of the population?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. 85 – 125 mg/dL

Explanation:

In a normal distribution, approximately 95% of the population’s values lie within ±2 standard deviations (SD) from the mean.

  • Mean = 105 mg/dL
  • SD = 10 mg/dL
  • Range for 95% = Mean ± (2 × SD) = 105 ± 20 = 85 to 125 mg/dL.

For normally distributed data, proportions within SD multiples are standard: ~68% within ±1 SD, ~95% within ±1.96 (≈±2) SD, ~99.7% within ±3 SD (empirical rule).

101 – 110 mg/dL (Option B): This is a much narrower range (±0.5 SD), covering far less than 95% of the population.

90 – 125 mg/dL (Option C): The lower limit is off; this is Mean − 1.5 SD to Mean + 2 SD, not a standard 95% range.

95 – 115 mg/dL (Option D): This is only Mean ± 1 SD, covering about 68% of the population.

questions.text: In a family with three siblings, the eldest sibling moves out of the household, and a new (third) child is born. What is this change in the family structure called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Complete extension

Explanation:

  • Here, a new child is born into the family, and at the same time, there are already other children in different stages (eldest has moved out, middle child still at home). Complete extension means the family grows with members in different stages of life - younger children, older children, and parents present in the family cycle.

Family life cycle: Sequence of changes a family undergoes over time. The main stages are:

  1. Formation: Creation of a new family unit (usually marriage or cohabitation).
  2. Extension: Addition of new members (e.g., birth of a child) without losing existing members.
  3. Complete Extension: Addition of members from multiple generations (e.g., grandparents moving in + birth of grandchildren).
  4. Contraction: Loss of members (e.g., children leaving home, death of elderly) without replacement.
  5. Complete Contraction: Loss of members leaving only one or two people in the family unit.
  6. Dissolution: The family unit breaks due to the death of one spouse (widow/widower remains).
  7. Extinction: Death of the last surviving family member.

Formation (Option A): Creation of a new family unit (e.g., marriage/cohabitation beginning a household); not applicable here because the family already exists.

Contraction (Option B): Reduction in family membership (death or permanent loss) without replacement; this scenario adds a member, so it is not contraction.

Extension (Option D): Refers to addition of members (e.g., a birth) but without the multi-stage/generational overlap

questions.text: A person has recently moved from Nigeria to the United States. Which of the following vaccines is required for international travel from Nigeria to the USA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Yellow Fever (17D) vaccine

Explanation:

  • Yellow fever is endemic in several African countries, including Nigeria. The WHO’s International Health Regulations require travelers from countries with risk of yellow fever transmission to present a valid yellow fever vaccination certificate when entering certain countries, including the USA. This prevents international spread of the disease.

Yellow Fever (17D) vaccine is a live-attenuated viral vaccine.

  • Single subcutaneous dose provides immunity for life
  • Required for travel from yellow fever-endemic areas to prevent spread to countries where the disease is not endemic.
  • Nigeria is a yellow fever endemic zone; hence proof of vaccination is mandatory.
  • Must be given at least 10 days before travel to be valid.
  • Contraindications: Infants <9 months, severe egg allergy, immunocompromised persons, pregnancy (relative).

Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccine (Option B): Recommended for travelers to rural Asia-Pacific regions, not Nigeria–USA travel.

Measles vaccine (Option C): Important for general immunization but not an international travel requirement between Nigeria and USA.

Rabies vaccine (Option D): Given for post-exposure prophylaxis or pre-exposure for high-risk groups, not a routine travel requirement for this route.

questions.text: A study was conducted using office records over the past 20 years to compare the incidence of disease among factory workers exposed to aniline dye and unexposed clerical staff. What type of epidemiological study is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Retrospective study

Explanation:

  • In this study, past office records were used to compare disease incidence between two groups: exposed and unexposed- over a 20-year period. Since the data were collected from past records and both exposure and outcome had already occurred before the start of the study, it is a retrospective study.
  • Retrospective study looks back in time using existing records or data. Both exposure and outcome have already occurred at the time the study starts. Often uses medical records, employment logs, or registries. Can be retrospective cohort if subjects are grouped by exposure and followed through past records to see outcomes.

Advantages: Less time-consuming, less expensive than prospective studies.

Limitations: Dependent on the accuracy and completeness of past records.

Types of analytical studies:

Cross-sectional

Case-control

Cohort

Ecological

Snapshot of population (survey)

Retrospective

(effect → cause)

Prospective

(cause / risk factor → effect)

Correlational (compare populations)

Prevalence

Study of choice: Rare diseases

Incidence

Correlation of variables

Odds ratio

Odds ratio

Relative risk, Attributable risk, Population attributable risk

–

Unit of study: Individual

Unit of study: Individual

Unit of study: Individual

Unit of study: Population

–

Recall bias

Attribution bias

Ecological fallacy

Prospective study (Option A): Follows subjects forward in time from exposure to outcome; here, data are already in the past.

Case-control study (Option C): Starts with diseased and non-diseased individuals, then looks back for exposure; here, groups were defined by exposure, not disease.

Ecological study (Option D): Compares populations or groups, not individuals; this study uses individual-level data.

questions.text: A patient whose diet mainly consists of pulses and rice presents with bowed legs (stick deformity). Which of the following vitamins could have prevented this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Vitamin D

Explanation:

  • The patient’s diet (mainly pulses and rice) is low in vitamin D and calcium-rich foods. Bowed legs (“stick deformity”) in this context indicate rickets, a disease of defective bone mineralization in children caused primarily by vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D is essential for calcium and phosphate absorption; its deficiency leads to soft bones and deformities.

Vitamin D & Rickets:

  • Sources:
    • Endogenous synthesis in skin via sunlight (UVB rays).
    • Dietary: fortified milk, egg yolk, fish liver oils.
  • Functions:
    • Enhances intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate.
    • Promotes bone mineralization.
    • Modulates immune function.
  • Deficiency Effects:
    • In children → Rickets: bowed legs, rachitic rosary, widening of wrists/ankles, delayed closure of fontanelle.
    • In adults → Osteomalacia.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Diet lacking in dairy/fortified foods.
    • Limited sunlight exposure.
    • Malabsorption syndromes.
  • Prevention:
    • Adequate sunlight exposure.
    • Vitamin D supplementation in high-risk groups.

Feature

Rickets (Children)

Osteomalacia (Adults)

Cause

Vitamin D deficiency

Vitamin D deficiency

Bone deformities

Yes (bow legs, knock knees)

No deformity, bone pain

Growth plate

Affected

Not affected

Vitamin A (Option A) – Deficiency causes night blindness, xerophthalmia; unrelated to bone deformities.

Vitamin B12 (Option B) – Deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms; not linked to rickets.

Vitamin C (Option C) – Deficiency causes scurvy (bleeding gums, poor wound healing); does not cause bowed legs.

questions.text: What does the Langelier Saturation Index (LSI) primarily indicate in water quality management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Water balance: scaling vs corrosion

Explanation:

  • The Langelier Saturation Index (LSI) is used to determine whether water will deposit calcium carbonate (scaling) or dissolve it (corrosion). A positive LSI means the water tends to deposit scale, while a negative LSI means it is likely to be corrosive.

LSI = (pH of water) – (pH at which water is saturated with calcium carbonate).

  • Positive LSI → Scaling tendency (CaCO₃ precipitation).
  • Negative LSI → Corrosion tendency (CaCO₃ dissolution).
  • Zero LSI → Water is in equilibrium (balanced).

Used in water treatment plants and industrial systems to maintain pipeline and equipment integrity.

Total dissolved solids in water (Option B): Measured separately; not the purpose of LSI.

Hardness of water only (Option C): LSI considers hardness along with pH, alkalinity, and temperature.

Presence of biological contaminants (Option D): Biological quality is assessed by microbiological tests, not LSI.

questions.text: A factory worker sustained burns covering 25% of his body while on duty. He later developed infections and complications related to the injury. Under the ESI Act, which of the following benefits is he eligible for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Extended Sickness Benefit

Explanation:

  • Under the Employees’ State Insurance (ESI) Act, Extended Sickness Benefit is provided to insured workers suffering from long-term illnesses that require prolonged treatment, including conditions that may develop as complications from injuries sustained at work. Since the factory worker’s burns led to infections and complications, he qualifies for extended sickness benefit, which is available for up to 2 years for specified diseases.

Extended Sickness Benefit:

  • Definition: Paid benefit under the ESI Act for insured persons suffering from certain long-term diseases requiring extended treatment.
  • Eligibility:
    • Must be an ESI-insured employee.
    • Must suffer from a disease on the prescribed list of 34 long-term diseases (including certain complications from burns and injuries).
    • Medical certification required.
  • Duration & Rate: Up to 2 years at a higher daily rate than the standard sickness benefit (usually 140% of standard rate).
  • Purpose: To ensure continued income for workers during prolonged illness.

Dependants’ Benefit (Option A): For dependants of an insured person who dies due to employment injury or occupational disease; not applicable here.

Sickness Benefit (Option B): Regular sickness benefit for up to 91 days in two benefit periods; not applicable for prolonged illness.

Enhanced Sickness Benefit (Option D): For sterilization procedures with higher compensation for a short duration; not applicable in this case.

questions.text: A group of experts delivered individual speeches on a common topic. There was no discussion allowed between them, and at the end, one person summarized the key points. What is this type of academic session called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Symposium

Explanation:

  • The correct answer is Symposium because it involves experts giving individual speeches on a single topic without interaction between them. At the end, a chairperson or moderator summarizes the content presented.

Panel discussion (Option A): Experts discuss a topic among themselves and respond to audience questions.

Seminar (Option C): In-depth study session, often interactive, on a specific topic for a small audience.

Workshop (Option D): Hands-on, practical training session with active participation.
